questions.text: A 35-year-old male complained of fatigue and passing dark-colored urine this morning. His blood reports showed an Hb of 10g/dL, and a peripheral smear showed normocytic normochromic anemia. His flow cytometry for RBCs is shown below. Which of the following is a likely finding when his blood smear is stained using crystal violet?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Heinz bodies:

  • Given the presenting complaints and lab reports, along with an RBC flow cytometry indicating a split population of RBCs with negative CD55 and CD59, the likely diagnosis is paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.
  • Blood smears from patients with PNH, stained with supravital dyes like crystal violet, show the presence of Heinz bodies.

 

  • Heinz bodies indicate oxidative damage to red blood cells. They are clumps of denatured hemoglobin attached to the cell membrane.
  • Using Romanowsky stains, these RBCs appear as “bite cells,” as these stains cannot demonstrate Heinz bodies.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bite cells:

  • RBCs in PNH when stained with Romanowsky stains show bite cells.

Option C- Helmet cells:

  • Helmet cells are fragmented RBCs seen Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome. They are also demonstrated using Romanowsky stains.

Option D- Sickle cells:

  • Sickle cells are crescent-shaped red blood cells characteristic of sickle cell anemia.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male basketball player is admitted to the hospital after injuring his shoulder during the game. Physical and radiographic examinations show the following injury, as noted in the following x-ray. Which of the following structures is most likely torn in this patient?

choices.text: Tendon of the long head of the biceps

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Acromioclavicular ligament:

  • This patient's x-ray shows the dislocation of the acromioclavicular joint (AC).
  • The AC joint is a diarthrodial joint defined by the lateral process of the clavicle articulating with the acromion process as it projects anteriorly off the scapula.
  • The joint is primarily stabilized by the acromioclavicular ligament, composed of anterior, posterior, inferior, and superior components.
  • The superior portion of the AC ligament is the most important component for the stability of the AC joint.
  • Supporting structures include two coracoclavicular ligaments (CC) (trapezoid and conoid ligaments), which provide vertical stability, as well as the coracoacromial ligament (AC).
  • AC injuries are frequently seen after sporting events, car accidents falling from a bicycle, and other sports-related activities.

Incorrect Options:

.Option A - Glenohumeral ligament:

  • The glenohumeral ligaments are thickening of the glenohumeral joint capsule and are involved in stabilizing the joint.

Option B - Coracoacromian ligament:

  • The coracoacromianligament is an integral component of the coracoacromial arch.
  • The coracoacromial ligament prevents overlapping of the humeral head.

Option C - Tendon of the long head of the biceps:

  • It is involved in the flexion of the forearm.
  • It has no role in the stabilization of the shoulder joint.

questions.text: The broncho-alveolar lavage of a patient infected with the Influenza A virus is stained with Toluidine blue. Identify the cells marked.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Mast Cells:

  • Toluidine blue staining is a useful method for counting basophils and mast cells.
  • Mast cells are involved in the immune response and can release histamine and other inflammatory mediators upon activation, which is often seen in viral infections like influenza.
  • The granules of basophils and mast cells stain purple and are distinct and separate. Nuclei stain blue, and cells with abundant RNA may show a blue tint in the cytoplasm. Toluidine blue staining does not distinguish between basophils and mast cells.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C:

  • The granules of Options A, B, and C are not typically demonstrated by toluidine blue. The granules of neutrophils, eosinophils, and azurophilic granules of monocytes may be demonstrated with dyes like 3,3′-diaminobenzidine or Sudan black.

questions.text:
A female patient presented with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge and intense itching. On examination, the cervix appears strawberry-like. Which of the following statements is true regarding the causative organism?


	Cyst is a diagnostic stage.
	Trophozoite is a diagnostic stage.
	Trophozoite is an infective stage.
	Cyst is an infective stage.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 2 and 3:

  • The clinical presentation of the patient is suggestive of trichomoniasis caused by trichomonas vaginalis.
  • Trichomonas vaginalis is the most common parasitic cause of sexually transmitted infection (STI). It produces vulvovaginitis, characterized by thin profuse foul smelling, purulent vaginal discharge, the strawberry appearance of the vaginal mucosa, and vaginal pH >4.5.
  • T. vaginalis exists only as a trophozoite (no cyst stage), which is both a diagnostic and infective stage of the organism.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text:
A patient is suspected of meningitis. On gram staining of his CSF, the following finding is made (shown in the image below). An antibiotic sensitivity for penicillin and cephalosporin was done and the minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) for each were found to be:


	Penicillin: >0.12 μg/mL
	Cephalosporin: >1 μg/mL


What specific antibiotic therapy can be used to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D - Cefotaxime + vancomycin:

  • The patient is suffering from pneumococcal meningitis.
  • The given image demonstrates gram positive, lanceolate-shaped cocci in pairs and chains indicating the causative to be Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • Based on the MIC values provided for the penicillin and cephalosporin, the patient is likely infected with a strain of Streptococcus pneumoniae that is resistant to both penicillin and cephalosporins:
    • Penicillin MIC >0.12 μg/mL indicates penicillin resistance.
    • Cephalosporin MIC >1 μg/mL indicates cephalosporin resistance.
  • (Cefotaxime or Ceftriaxone or Cefepime) in combination with vancomycin is recommended to cover resistant strains of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Incorrect Answer:

Option A - Penicillin G:

  • Penicillin MIC >0.12 μg/mL indicates penicillin resistance and hence cannot be used in this case.

Option B - Nafcillin:

  • Nafcillin is indicated for methicillin- sensitive Staphylococcal CNS infections

Option C - Ceftriaxone:

  • In case of a MIC ≤0.5 μg/mL for cephalosporins (indicating sensitivity), monotherapy with cefotaxime or ceftriaxone is usually adequate.

questions.text: A female child was brought with complaints of urine dribbling. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bladder exstrophy:

  • The presentation of urine dribbling and the image are suggestive of bladder exstrophy caused by the failure of the mesoderm to invade the cephalad extension of the cloacal membrane.
  • Bladder exstrophy is characterized by protrusion of the bladder from the abdominal wall and exposure of the mucosa. The umbilicus is displaced downward, the pubic rami are widely separated in the midline, and the rectus muscles are separated.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Omphalocele: It is a congenital abdominal wall defect where abdominal organs, such as the liver and intestines, herniate through the umbilicus and are covered by a translucent sac or membrane.

Option B – Gastroschisis: In gastroschisis, there is a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus, and the abdominal organs, usually the intestines, protrude directly through the defect without a sac or membrane covering.

Option D - Cloacal exstrophy: It is characterized by exstrophy of the urinary bladder and large intestine through an abdominal wall defect, anal atresia, hypoplasia of the colon, omphalocele, and anomalous genitalia.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for the ECG shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Wenckebach heart block:

  • The given ECG shows progressive PR elongation, eventually leading to a dropped QRS complex. This is indicative of a second-degree AV block, Mobitz Type I, or Wenckebach heart block.
  • A second-degree heart block occurs when there is intermittent failure of electrical impulse conduction from the atrium to the ventricle. It is characterized by a missed QRS complex

Incorrect Options:

Option A - First-degree heart block:

  • In first-degree heart block, a prolonged PR interval of 200ms is seen which indicates a slowing of conduction between the atria and ventricle.

Option C - Mobitz Type-II heart block:

  • Mobitz Type-II is characterized by an ECG showing regular PR intervals with a sudden dropped QRS complex.

Option D - Third-degree heart block:

  • In third-degree heart block, the P wave and the QRS complex are completely dissociated. This occurs due to the complete blockage of impulse transmission from the AV node to the ventricles.

questions.text:
A testicular mass shows the following feature:



What is the probable pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Leydig cell tumor:

  • The image demonstrates Reinke's crystalloid. Reinke crystals are rod-like cytoplasmic inclusions that are typically found in the cells of Leydig cell tumors.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Granulosa cell tumor:

  • This type of tumor is primarily associated with the ovary, although rare testicular cases can occur. Microscopically, it shows Call Exner Bodies and coffee bean nuclei.

Option B - Sertoli cell tumor:

  • Sertoli cell tumors are another type of sex cord-stromal tumor of the testis; microscopically, the tubules are lined by uniform columnar cells with basal nuclei and abundant clear cytoplas

Option D - Yolk Sac Tumor:

  • This is a type of germ cell tumor that is common in children and does not contain Reinke crystals. On histology, it typically shows Schiller-Duval/Glomeruloid bodies.

questions.text: The device shown in the image is _______.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Automated external defibrillator:

  • An automated external defibrillator (AED) is a portable electronic device used to detect and manage life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias.
  • AEDs are microprocessor-controlled devices that are capable of electrocardiographic analysis with very high specificity and sensitivity in differentiating shockable from non-shockable rhythms.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of the given pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Aqueductal stenosis:

  • The given image reveals the findings of an enlarged head with a sunset eye appearance suggestive of hydrocephalus due to enlarged ventricles, which are fluid-filled spaces within the brain caused most commonly by aqueductal stenosis.
  • Aqueductal stenosis is a condition characterized by a narrowing or obstruction of the aqueduct of Sylvius, a narrow passage connecting the third and fourth ventricles in the brain. When this passage is narrowed or blocked, the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is obstructed, leading to fluid accumulation in the ventricles and ventriculomegaly.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. These conditions lead to ventriculomegaly but are not the most common cause.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding the immunological abnormality seen in the absence of CD 40 ligand on mature B cells?

1) Serum shows elevated IgM.

2) Serum shows absence of IgA, IgE, and extremely low levels of IgG.

3) Defective CD4+ helper T and B cell interaction.

4) Defective leukocyte adhesion is seen.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1, 2, and 3:

The absence of CD40 ligand (CD40L) on T cells results in Hyper-IgM syndrome.

  1. Serum shows elevated IgM: The absence of CD40L prevents B cells from undergoing class switch recombination from IgM to other immunoglobulin classes, leading to elevated levels of IgM.
  2. The serum shows the absence of IgA, IgE, and extremely low levels of IgG: Without CD40L, B cells cannot switch to producing IgA, IgE, or IgG, resulting in their absence or extremely low levels.
  3. Defective CD4+ helper T and B cell interaction: CD40L is critical for the interaction between CD4+ T helper cells and B cells, which is necessary for B cell activation and class switching.
  4. Defective leukocyte adhesion is seen: It is a characteristic of Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency (LAD), not hyper-IgM syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text: An 18-year-old female came with complaints of irregular menses. She was diagnosed with PCOS two months back and was advised to maintain a diet and exercise. She failed to follow the advice and now has developed acne and facial hair. What is the appropriate treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Reassure the patient to follow diet and exercise diligently

questions.solution:
Correct Option C- OCPs + Cyproterone acetate:

  • The most appropriate treatment for this patient, considering her diagnosis and current symptoms, is OCPs + Cyproterone acetate. This treatment will help regulate her menstrual cycles and effectively address the symptoms of hyperandrogenism, including acne and facial hair.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Reassure the patient to follow diet and exercise diligently:

  • While lifestyle modification is essential in managing PCOS, this option alone is insufficient for managing the acute symptoms of acne and facial hair.

Option B- Exercise + Topical Eflornithine Hydrochloride:

  • Exercise is beneficial, but topical treatments like Eflornithine Hydrochloride primarily reduce hair growth and do not address hormonal imbalances or irregular menses.

Option C- OCPs:

  • While oral contraceptive pills can help, the combination with Cyproterone acetate is more effective for managing androgen-related symptoms.

questions.text:
Calculate the anion gap for a patient with the following electrolyte levels:
Na+: 140mEq/L, K+: 5mEq/L, Cl-: 87mEq/L, HCO3-: 21mEq/L
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- 32 mEq/L:

  • The anion gap is calculated by the formula:
    • Na+ - (Cl- + HCO3-).
    • Substituting the values of the patient:
    • 140- (87+21) = 140- 108 = 32 mEq/L
    • The anion gap in this patient is 32 mEq/L

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A male who recently returned from Africa presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain and hemorrhagic manifestations. He died despite treatment, and an autopsy revealed intranuclear Torres bodies in the liver. Which of the following vaccines with which strain could have prevented it?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 17 D:

  • The presence of the Torres body (cowdry A intranuclear inclusion bodies) on autopsy in a patient with a history of hemorrhagic manifestation is suggestive of yellow fever, which is caused by the yellow fever virus.
  • The 17D strain is a live attenuated vaccine that provides immunity against yellow fever. It is recommended for travelers to areas where yellow fever is endemic.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Edmonston-Zagreb strain: Edmonston-Zagreb strain is used for the preparation of live attenuated vaccine for measles.

Option C - Jeryl Lynn strain: The Jeryl Lynn strain is used for the preparation of the live virus vaccine against mumps.

Option D - Nakayama vaccine: The Nakayama strain is used for the preparation of the formalin-inactivated mouse brain vaccine against Japanese encephalitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is matched incorrectly?

choices.text: Individuals consider themselves special and expect special treatment - Histrionic Personality Disorder
Pervasive disrespect for and infringement on the rights of others seen in a 19-year-old- Antisocial Personality Disorder
Displaying remote reserve and lack of involvement with everyday events and concerns of others- Schizoid Personality Disorder
Excessive suspiciousness and distrust of others, interpreting their actions as deliberately harmful or deceitful - Paranoid Personality Disorder

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Individuals consider themselves special and expect special treatment - Histrionic Personality Disorder:

  • Histrionic Personality Disorder is actually characterized by attention-seeking behavior, exaggeration of emotions, and dramatic actions, but not necessarily by a grandiose sense of self-importance and entitlement. The latter is more characteristic of narcissistic personality disorder.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pervasive disrespect for and infringement on the rights of others seen in a 19-year-old- Antisocial Personality Disorder: The key characteristics of antisocial personality disorder include a consistent disregard for and violation of the rights of others. To be diagnosed with this disorder, an individual must be 18 years old or older, have shown this behavioral pattern since the age of 15, and have exhibited signs of conduct disorder before reaching the age of 15.

Option C - Displaying remote reserve and lack of involvement with everyday events and concerns of others- Schizoid Personality Disorder: People with schizoid personality disorder come across as cold and distant. They tend to be reserved, showing little interest in everyday events or other people's issues. They are quiet, isolated, and prefer to be alone. They may live their lives without much desire for emotional connections and are usually unaware of changes in popular trends.

Option D - Excessive suspiciousness and distrust of others, interpreting their actions as deliberately harmful or deceitful- Paranoid Personality Disorder: The key characteristics of paranoid personality disorder include an excessive level of suspicion and distrust of others, leading to a consistent tendency to interpret others' actions as intentionally demeaning, malevolent, threatening, exploitative, or deceptive. This behavior typically begins in early adulthood. Individuals with this disorder almost always anticipate being exploited or harmed by others in some manner.

questions.text: The given electron microscopic findings of the glomerular basement membrane are typically seen in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Alport syndrome:

  • The given image shows an abnormally split and laminated basement membrane leading to a characteristic “Basketweave” appearance. This is a characteristic feature of Alport syndrome.
  • Alport syndrome is typically caused by mutations in the genes encoding type IV collagen, particularly the COL4A5 gene, which affects the alpha-5 chain of type IV collagen.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Minimal change disease:

  • This disease is characterized by the effacement of podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy without changes to the basement membrane itself.

Option C - MPGN-I (Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis):

  • This condition typically shows subepithelial immune deposits leading to a "spike and dome" appearance on electron microscopy.

Option D - Dense Deposit Disease:

  • Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis Type II (MPGN-II), also known as Dense Deposit Disease, is characterized by intramembranous dense deposits within the glomerular basement membrane.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			JVP Waveform Component 
			
			
			Corresponding Event 
			
		
		
			
			
				A wave
				Y descent
				V wave
				C wave
			
			
			
			a. Atrial contraction

			b. Passive atrial relaxation

			c. Tricuspid valve bulging into the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.

			d. Atrial filling against closed tricuspid valve

			e. Passive emptying of the right atrium into the ventricle due to opening of the tricuspid valve.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1-a, 2-e, 3-d, 4-c:

A jugular venous pulse can be characterized by two waveforms:

  • Positive waves:
    • a wave: It represents atrial presystolic contraction.
    • c wave: It represents the tricuspid valve bulging into the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
    • v wave: It represents atrial filling against a closed tricuspid valve.
  • Negative waves:
    • X and X¢ descent: It represents passive atrial relaxation.
    • Y descent: It represents the passive emptying of the right atrium into the ventricle due to the opening of the tricuspid valve.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text:
The following Lineweaver Burk plot is suggestive of ______.

Redline- with inhibitor

Backline – without inhibitor
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Non-competitive inhibitor:

  • The Lineweaver Burk plot in the given question is suggestive of non-competitive inhibition.
    • Vmax is the maximum velocity of a reaction.
    • Km is the substrate concentration at which velocity is half maximum.
  • In the case of a non-competitive inhibitor, the inhibitor binds to the enzyme in a different site of the enzyme than that of the substrate, resulting in the same Km value in the presence or the absence of the inhibitor.
  • Increasing the concentration of the substrate does not overcome this inhibition. Therefore, the maximum velocity of the reaction decreases in non-competitive inhibition, as depicted in the graph.

Incorrect Options:
Option A - Competitive inhibitor:

  • In this, the inhibitor competes with the substrate to bind at the site of substrate binding. Increasing the substrate concentration in the solution can overcome this inhibition thus turn, there is no alteration in the velocity (Vmax)of the reaction upon increasing the substrate concentration (Km).

Option C - Uncompetitive inhibitor:

  • In this, the inhibitor binds to the enzyme-substrate complex but not to the free enzyme. In such cases, both Vmax and Km are decreased.

Option D - Suicide inhibitor:

  • In suicide inhibition, the inhibitor makes use of the enzyme's own reaction mechanism to inactivate it.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought with complaints of not attaining menarche. She has cyclical pelvic pain and well-developed secondary sexual characteristics. Examination of the lower abdomen reveals a suprapubic bulge; PR corresponds to this by showing a bulging swelling in the anterior wall. What is the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Transverse vaginal septum above the vagina

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Imperforate hymen:

  • The most likely diagnosis in this scenario is cryptomenorrhea due to imperforate hymen.
  • Imperforate hymen results due to failure of canalization of the inferior end of the vaginal plate.
  • The patient presents with primary amenorrhea, cyclical abdominal pain, and a bluish bulging membrane at the vaginal opening on genital examination (on Valsalva maneuver).
  • USG of the pelvis, in this case, will show normal internal genitalia with hematocolpos.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vaginal atresia:

  • Vaginal atresia is the congenital absence of the lower portion of the vagina. Upon examination, a normal hymenal ring is present, and proximal to it, only a vaginal dimple or small pouch is found.

Option C - Cervical agenesis:

  • Cervical agenesis is the congenital absence of the cervix, typically with a normal uterus. If there is normal endometrium, the patient may present with a distended uterus. On examination, the absence of a cervix is noted.

Option D - Transverse vaginal septum above the vagina:

  • This occurs due to failure of the Mullerian duct fusion, and on examination, the vagina may appear shortened with an unidentifiable cervix. Diagnosis is only confirmed by USG or MRI.
  • On vaginal examination, a pinkish concave covering may be seen.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man, a known case of ADPKD came with complaints of fever and flank pain accompanied by nausea and vomiting. A CT-PET confirms a cyst infection. What is the ideal treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cotrimoxazole:

  • Lipid-soluble antibiotics such as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (Cotrimoxazole), quinolones, and chloramphenicol are effective against common gram-negative enteric organisms. They are preferred for cyst infection due to their lipid solubility, which allows them to penetrate cyst walls effectively. Treatment often requires 4–6 weeks.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and D may be used as parenteral treatments before fluoroquinolone in UTIs with high-risk E. coli resistance.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect in a patient with the following lesion in his forearm?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Radiosensitive:

  • An ulcerative lesion in a preexisting scar tissue due to burns, as seen in the image, is suggestive of Marjolin’s ulcer.
  • Marjolin’s ulcer is a cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma arising in chronic wounds or burn scars that are radioresistant in nature due to the avascularity of the scar tissue. Therefore, radiotherapy is not preferred in these cases.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Painless: Marjolin’s ulcer is usually painless due to damage to the nerve in a pre-existing scar from burns.

Option C - Squamous cell carcinoma: Marjolin’s ulcer is a cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma.

Option D - IOC is biopsy: Biopsy is the investigation of choice revealing keratinocyte dysplasia involving the full thickness of the epidermis without infiltration of atypical cells into the dermis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Child-Pugh classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bleeding time:

  • Bleeding time is not a component of Child-Pugh classification.
  • Child-Pugh classification is used to grade the severity of liver dysfunction.

Parameter

1 point

2 Points

3 Points

Ascites

Absent

Slight

Moderate

Bilirubin

<2 mg/dL (<34.2 micromol/L

2 to 3 mg/dL (34.2 to 51.3 micromol/L

>3 mg/dL (>51.3 micromol/L)

Albumin

>3.5 g/dL (35 g/L)

2.8 to 3.5 g/dL (28 to 35 g/L)

<2.8 g/dL (<28 g/L)

Prothrombin time

< 4 seconds over control or INR <1.7

4 to 6 seconds over control or INR 1.7 to 2.3

>6 seconds over control or INR >2.3

Encephalopathy

None

Grade 1 to 2

Grade 3 to 4

Based on the scoring on each component the severity of liver dysfunction is classified into 3 classes:

  • Class A: 5-6 points (well-compensated disease)
  • Class B: 7-9 points (significant functional compromise)
  • Class C: 10-15 points (decompensated disease)

Incorrect Options:

Options: A, B and D are components of Child-Pugh classification.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of intermittent episodes of flushing and diarrhea. The patient's stool shows an osmolar gap of less than 50 mOsm and has a rice-water appearance. The lab investigation reveals a potassium level of 2.8 mmol/L. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - WDHA syndrome:

  • The patient's presentation is suggestive of WDHA syndrome (Watery Diarrhea, Hypokalemia, Achlorhydria), also known as VIPoma syndrome.
  • This condition is caused by excessive secretion of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) by a tumor, leading to the symptoms of flushing, diarrhea, and electrolyte disturbances such as hypokalemia.
  • The stool osmolar gap of less than 50 mOsm indicates that the diarrhea is due to excessive secretion of fluid into the intestinal lumen, which is characteristic of VIPoma syndrome (WDHA syndrome).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Carcinoid syndrome:

  • Carcinoid syndrome can present with flushing and diarrhea, but it typically involves elevated levels of serotonin and urinary 5-HIAA.
  • Additionally, the osmolar gap and rice-water appearance of the stool are not characteristic of carcinoid syndrome.

Option C - Glucagonoma:

  • Glucagonomas are pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors that can cause a characteristic syndrome including necrolytic migratory erythema, diabetes mellitus, weight loss, and stomatitis.
  • While diarrhea can occur, it's not typically associated with a rice-water appearance of stool or significant hypokalemia.

Option D - Somatostatinoma:

  • Somatostatinomas are rare pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors that can cause diarrhea due to the inhibitory effect of somatostatin on gastrointestinal motility.
  • However, somatostatinomas are more commonly associated with diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, and steatorrhea than with hypokalemia and a rice-water appearance of stool.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with enlarged adenoids presents with complaints of reduced hearing for the past 1 month. The following finding was observed in the otoscope. Which of the following will be recommended?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Valsalva manoeuvre and observation:

  • The clinical presentation of hearing loss and otoscopic finding of the dull tympanic membrane with absent light reflex, retracted tympanic membrane, and presence of air bubbles are suggestive of serous otitis media.
  • The initial management of this condition is symptomatic relief of nasal congestion, steroid administration, and repeated Valsalva maneouvre to ventilate the middle ear and observation for 3 months.
  • Surgical intervention is required when medical management alone does not help. It involves myringotomy, grommet insertion, or management of the cause, like adenoidectomy in this case.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and C are incorrect: Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presented with bleeding gum. Her lab reports showed Hb 9g/dl and platelet 23,000/mL. She had raised PT and aPTT. A bone marrow biopsy is done as shown below. What is the likely chromosomal defect in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - t(15:17):

  • The likely diagnosis of this patient is AML M3/ Acute promyelocytic leukemia. This specific type of leukemia is most commonly associated with the chromosomal translocation t(15;17)- PML-RARA fusion. This subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is characterized by the presence of abnormal promyelocytes containing multiple Auer rods. Patients often present with symptoms such as bleeding due to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), which explains the patient's bleeding gums, low platelet count, and abnormal coagulation tests (raised PT and aPTT).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - t(8:21):

  • This translocation is associated with AML-M2. (RUNX1-RUNX1T1 fusion)

Option B - Inversion of Chromosome 16:

  • This genetic abnormality is associated with AML-M4. The patient has eosinophilia.

Option C - t(9:22):

  • This translocation, also known as the Philadelphia chromosome, is associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

questions.text: The following audiogram is characteristic of ______.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Noise-induced hearing loss:

  • The audiogram is of the right side ear with sensorineural hearing loss characterized by an acoustic dip, aka boiler’s notch, i.e., dip at 4 KHz for both air conduction and bone conduction is characteristic of noise-induced hearing loss.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Otosclerosis: Otosclerosis is characterized by a Carhartt notch, i.e., dip at 2 KHz in bone conduction and abnormal air conduction.

Option B - Menier’s disease: Menier’s disease is characterized by sensorineural hearing loss and an up-sloping graph, i.e., hearing loss at the low frequency of sounds.

Option C – Presbycusis: Presbycusis is characterized by sensorineural hearing loss and a downsloping graph, i.e., hearing loss at high frequency.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about DEPOT preparations and their administration is correct?

choices.text: DEPOT preparations are designed to accelerate the onset of action by making drugs more water-soluble.
Haloperidol decanoate is an example of a DEPOT preparation made by attaching a lipid moiety to haloperidol to prolong its action.
The zigzag technique is used to ensure faster absorption of drugs administered intramuscularly.
Staining of subcutaneous fat occurs frequently with the use of iron dextran injection and cannot be prevented.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Haloperidol decanoate is an example of a DEPOT preparation made by attaching a lipid moiety to haloperidol to prolong its action:

  • Haloperidol decanoate is a DEPOT preparation formed by attaching a lipid moiety (undecanoate) to haloperidol. This modification makes the drug lipid-soluble, resulting in slower absorption and a longer duration of action.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - DEPOT preparations are designed to accelerate the onset of action by making drugs more water-soluble:

  • DEPOT preparations are not designed to accelerate the onset of action. Instead, they are formulated to slow down the absorption and extend the duration of action by making drugs more lipid-soluble, not water-soluble.

Option C - The zigzag technique is used to ensure faster absorption of drugs administered intramuscularly:

  • The zigzag (or Z-track) technique is used to prevent the drug from leaking back through the puncture site, thereby avoiding staining of subcutaneous fat. It is not used to ensure faster absorption; rather, it is to ensure the drug stays in the muscle.

Option D - Staining of subcutaneous fat occurs frequently with the use of iron dextran injection and cannot be prevented:

  • Staining of subcutaneous fat can occur with iron dextran injections, but it can be prevented using the zigzag (Z-track) technique. This method reduces the likelihood of the drug leaking back to the subcutaneous tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments are not used in laparoscopic surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

  • This is a Beckman Weitlaner Retractor characterized by 2-6 blunt/sharp outward-curving prongs.
  • It is used to retract/hold back the tissue or bone for exposure during open surgeries.

Incorrect Options:

Option A -Veress needle, Option B - Trocar, Option D- Hasson cannula - are used in laparoscopic surgery.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of sound-induced vertigo. Which of the following conditions is not associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Otosclerosis:

  • Loud sound-induced vertigo, aka Tullio’s phenomenon, is a common complaint due to stapes footplate movement by a distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate as seen in Meniere’s disease or following activation of the stapes reflex seen in superior semicircular canal dehiscence. This results in an abnormal pressure wave through the inner ear, resulting in vertigo.
  • A positive Tullio's phenomenon is seen in:
    • Meniere’s disease
    • Perilymph fistula
    • Congenital syphilis
    • Superior semicircular canal dehiscence.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect: Tullio’s phenomenon is associated with these conditions.

questions.text: A sewage worker presented with high-grade fever, jaundice, and blood in the urine for the past 5 days. His creatinine levels are raised. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Microscopic agglutination test:

  • The clinical presentation of the patient is suggestive of Weil's disease, aka hepatorenal syndrome, a bacterial infection caused by pathogenic Leptospira interrogans. 
  • The microscopic agglutination test (MAT) is the most appropriate and specific serological test for diagnosing leptospirosis. It detects specific antibodies produced by the patient in response to Leptospira infection. The test involves exposing a patient's serum sample to a panel of live Leptospira serovars and observing for agglutination (clumping) of the bacteria.
  • The highest dilution of the serum that shows agglutination is reported as the titer and helps determine the serovar of Leptospira involved in the infection.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cold agglutination test: This test is used for diagnosing mycoplasma.

Option C - Standard agglutination test: This test is used for diagnosing brucellosis.

Option D - Paul-Bunnell test: The Paul-Bunnell test, also known as the Monospot test, is used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis, primarily caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of reversible dementia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Lewy Body Dementia:

  • Lewy body dementia is typically an irreversible form of dementia.
  • Lewy Body Dementia (LBD) is a progressive degenerative brain disorder characterized by dementia, psychosis, and symptoms of parkinsonism. Symptoms vary and change over time among different individuals. It is the third most common type of dementia, following Alzheimer's disease and Vascular dementia.
  • Causes of dementia:

Reversible causes

Irreversible causes
  • Autoimmune encephalopathy
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Brain Tumor
  • Subdural Hematoma
  • Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus
  • Thiamine deficiency
  • B12 deficiency
  • Lewy body dementia
  • Parkinson’s disease
  • Huntington’s disease
  • Vascular dementia
  • Fronto temporal dementia
  • Creutzfeld-Jacob disease

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and C cause reversible forms of dementia.

questions.text:
Match the following developmental milestones.


	
		
			
			1. Transfers objects

			2. Standing with support

			3. Mature pincer grasp

			4. Sitting without support
			
			
			a. 9-10 months

			b. 6-7 months

			c. 7-8 months

			d. 11-12 months
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c:

  • Fine motor developmental milestone:
    • Transfer objects/unidextrous reach is achieved by the age of 6 months.
    • Mature pincer grasp is achieved by the age of 12 months (immature pincer grasp – 9 months).
  • Gross motor developmental milestone:
    • Sitting without support is achieved by the age of 8 months.
    • Standing with support is achieved by the age of 9 months.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect.

questions.text: Which specific neurotransmitter is accountable for causing dilation of the small intestine in a forward direction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - NO:

  • Nitric oxide (NO) is a neurotransmitter released when the cholinergic neuron from the myenteric plexus moves in the anterograde direction of the peristalsis.
  • It acts as a relaxant on smooth muscles in the proximal segment of the segment containing chyme, resulting in relaxation of the proximal segment of the chyme and movement of the content towards the rectum.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Serotonin: Serotonin is a neurotransmitter that is secreted by the gastric epithelial cells in response to stretch due to food. It is responsible for the activation of myenteric plexus, resulting in coordinated movements of retrograde contraction and anterograde relaxation in peristalsis.

Options B and D are incorrect. Acetylcholine and substance P are released by cholinergic neurons in the retrograde direction of the peristalsis and result in the contraction of the smooth muscle.

questions.text:
Match the following instruments with their application.


	
		
			
			Instrument
			
			
			Use
			
		
		
			
			1.
			
			
			a. Engages optic nerve
			
		
		
			
			2. 
			
			
			b. To create an opening in a bone
			
		
		
			
			3. 
			
			
			c. Fixation of chalazion
			
		
		
			
			4. 
			
			
			d. To separate uveal tissue from sclera
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b:

The instruments shown are:

  1. The instrument is called a chalazion clamp. It consists of two limbs like a forceps, which can be clamped with the help of a screw. It is used to fix the chalazion and achieve hemostasis during the incision and curettage operation.
  2. The instrument is called an evisceration spatula. It consists of a small but sturdy rectangular blade with a slightly convex surface and blunt edges, attached to a handle. It is used to separate the uveal tissue from the sclera during an evisceration operation.
  3. The instrument is called an enucleation spoon or optic nerve guide. It is a spoon-shaped instrument with a central cleavage. It is used to engage the optic nerve during enucleation.
  4. The instrument is called a bone punch. It consists of a stout spring handle and two blades attached at the right angle. It is used to enlarge the bony opening during DCR operation by punching the bone from the margins of the opening.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 45-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with a small mass in her vulva. She denies having multiple sexual partners but has a history treated C.trachomatis. A swelling is seen on examination, as shown in the image below. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Excision and biopsy:

  • The likely diagnosis in this patient is an asymptomatic Bartholin cyst. Chlamydia trachomatis is a known pathogen that can lead to infections of the Bartholin glands. In most cases an asymptomatic Bartholin cyst is treated conservatively however, given that the patient is post menopausal and over 40 years of age, neoplasia needs to be excluded. After menopause, Bartholin gland duct cysts and abscesses are rare and should raise concern for possible neoplasia. Hence, the appropriate next step would be excision and biopsy.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are not recommended in this patient, as an exclusion of neoplasia must be established.

  • In cases of asymptomatic Bartholin cysts, conservative management may be sufficient. In case of a large cyst or cyst infection with incision, drainage, or marsupialization.

questions.text: Where is the location of the lesion resulting in the following visual field defect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Left Temporal radiations:

  • The visual field defect shown in the image is of the right side superior homonymous quadrantanopia, i.e., pie in the sky.
  • The lesion will be in the left side temporal radiations because the inferior fibers of the optic radiations, which serve the upper visual fields, first sweep anteroinferior into the temporal lobe around the anterior tip of the temporal horn of the lateral ventricle called Meyer’s loop.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Left Optic tract: Lesion at left optic tract will result in right-sided homonymous hemianopia.

Option B - Optic chiasma: Lesion at optic chiasma will result in bitemporal hemianopia.

Option C - Left Anterior parietal radiations: Lesion at left anterior parietal lesion will result in right inferior quadrantanopia, i.e., pie on the floor because the superior fibers of the radiations, which subserve the inferior visual fields, proceed directly posteriorly through the parietal lobe to the occipital cortex.

questions.text: The patient belongs to which class of Mallampatti classification is ______.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Class 0:

  • The examination of the oral cavity and oropharynx to assess the ease of intubation is classified by the Mallampatti score.
  • The given finding is suggestive of class 0 because of the presence of the tip of the epiglottis, as seen in the image. It is seen only when a previous airway surgery was performed on a patient.

  • Other classes of Mallampatti scoring according to visible structures are:
    • Class 1: Hard palate, soft palate, pillar of tonsillar fossa, and uvula is visible. (normally visible structures).
    • Class 2: Tip of uvula is not seen, rest of the structures are seen.
    • Class 3: Hard palate, soft palate, and base of the uvula are seen.
    • Class 4: Only the hard palate is seen.

Incorrect Options:
Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Wrigley’s forceps:

  • The given image shows Wrigley’s forceps. The instrument is short and has a marked cephalic curve with a slight pelvic curve. It is used to provide traction force in Operative vaginal delivery.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Kielland’s forceps:

  • These are long, almost straight forceps without an axis-traction device. Kielland’s forceps are known for their ability to correct asynclitism (misalignment of the fetal head) due to their sliding mechanism, and the small knob on each blade is designed to fit the occiput.

Option C- Piper’s forceps:

  • Piper's forceps have a distinct perineal curve and are used to deliver the aftercoming head in a breech delivery.

Option D- Tucker-McLane forceps:

  • Tucker-McLane forceps are used for the fetal head with little molding and for rotational delivery.

questions.text: The prevalence of diabetes in a community has recently decreased from 90% to 60%. Which of the following statements regarding the screening test is most accurate?

choices.text: The test's sensitivity and specificity are both affected.
The negative predictive value (NPV) of the test is decreased.
Both the positive predictive value (PPV) and NPV of the test have increased.
The PPV of the test is decreased.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - The PPV of the test is decreased:

  • Higher Prevalence = Higher Positive Predictive Value (PPV): When a disease is more prevalent in a population, the probability of a positive test result correctly indicating the presence of the disease (true positive) increases. This is because there are more true positives relative to false positives in a high-prevalence setting.
  • Less False Positives = Increased Specificity: Specificity refers to the ability of a test to correctly identify those without the disease (true negatives). In a high-prevalence setting, the test may produce more false positives (incorrectly identifying individuals without the disease as positive), leading to a decrease in specificity. However, in a low-prevalence setting, there are fewer false positives, resulting in increased specificity.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and C are incorrect due to the above given explanation.

questions.text: Which of the following anticoagulants can be used to carry out the ESR test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Trisodium citrate:

  • For estimating erythrocyte sedimentation rates, blood is anticoagulated with 3.8% trisodium citrate (Blue tube) when the Westergren method is performed. Ethylene diamine tetra acetic acid (EDTA) (violet tube) is used when the Winthrobe method is performed.
  • Hence, of the given options, the appropriate anticoagulant for ESR would be Trisodium citrate.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sodium Fluoride: Sodium Fluoride is used as an anticoagulant additive for Blood Glucose Estimation in grey tube.

Option B - Heparin: Heparin (green tube) is used as an anticoagulant when the sample is taken for arterial blood gas or osmotic fragility test.

Option C - Potassium Oxalate: In glucose estimator tests, Potassium oxalate with NaF as an additive is used in a grey tube.

questions.text: The most common site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is_______.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – 3:

  • The most common site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of the Rosenmuller.
  • It is present in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx.
  • On the lateral wall is the opening of the auditory (eustachian) tube marked by 1. This opening is surrounded by a prominent ridge called the torus tubaris marked by 2, which is formed by the medial end of the cartilaginous auditory tube. Behind the torus, there is a narrow space known as the fossa of Rosenmuller marked by 3.

Incorrect Options:

Options A and B are incorrect: Refer to Option C for an explanation.

Option D – 4: The structure is the posterior part of the nasal septum.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV patient complained of painful lesions in his oral cavity (as shown below). A biopsy of the lesion showed the proliferation of spindle-shaped cells. These cells expressed markers for both endothelial cells and smooth muscle cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Kaposi Sarcoma:

  • The HIV patient presents with a violaceous growth on the hard palate, which is diagnostic of Kaposi sarcoma (KS). The biopsy reports of spindle cell proliferation are further confirmation of the disease.
  • KS is a vascular neoplasm caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) and is common in AIDS patients. It is considered an AIDS-defining illness and is the most common malignancy associated with HIV infection.
  • Oral KS often involves the hard and soft palate, gingiva, and dorsal tongue. The lesion may be non-pigmented, brownish-red, or violaceous.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Squamous Cell Carcinoma:

  • SCC typically presents as a non-healing ulcer or mass in the oral cavity and is characterized histologically by the presence of malignant squamous cells and keratin pearls (in well-differentiated cases)

Option C - Basal Cell Carcinoma:

  • BCC is typically found on sun-exposed skin. It presents histologically as nests of basaloid cells.

Option D - Malignant Melanoma:

  • This can present in the oral cavity as a pigmented lesion and histologically shows atypical melanocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is most likely associated with this tongue appearance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cyanocobalamin:

  • Beefy Red Tongue: Vitamin B12 Deficiency.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Riboflavin:

  • Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin) deficiency result in a Magenta red Tongue Also known as Geographical Tongue.

Option B - Pyridoxine:

  • Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) is associated with Microcytic anemia and Peripheral neuropathy.

Option C - Folate:

  • Vitamin B9 (Folate) is associated with Cheilosis and glossitis but the geographical tongue is caused by B2 deficiency.

questions.text:
What is the degree of placenta previa when image B shows the extent of involvement of the internal is on transvaginal ultrasound?

A. B.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Type II:

  • The given image shows placenta previa type II or Marginal. The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.

Incorrect Answer:

Option A - Type IV:

  • Type IV (Central or complete): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

Option B - Type III:

  • Type III (Incomplete or partial central) placenta previa is characterized by the placenta partially covering the internal os. Specifically, the placenta covers the internal os when it is closed but does not entirely do so when it is fully dilated.

Option D - Type I:

  • In this condition, the majority of the placenta is attached to the upper uterine segment, with only the lower margin extending into the lower uterine segment but not reaching the cervical

questions.text: At 36 weeks of pregnancy, a woman complained of feeling dizzy and lightheaded when lying on her back. These symptoms are relieved when she turns to her side. She does not experience the same symptoms when standing or walking. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?

choices.text: Excessive venous pooling at the feet

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - IVC compression:

  • During the later stages of pregnancy, the enlarged uterus can compress the inferior vena cava when the woman is lying on her back. This compression usually results in the opening up of collateral circulation through the paravertebral and azygos veins. In some cases, the collateral circulation is unable to open and reduces venous return to the heart, leading to decreased cardiac output and subsequent symptoms of dizziness and lightheadedness. The relief of symptoms when turning to the side is consistent with alleviating the pressure on the IVC.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Excessive venous pooling at the feet:

  • This typically occurs when standing or sitting for prolonged periods, not when lying down.

Option B - Increased intracranial pressure:

  • This condition causes symptoms such as headache, visual disturbances, and nausea. A retinal examination shows papilledema.

Option C - Heavy metal poisoning:

  • This condition would have a range of systemic symptoms depending on the specific metal involved, but it would not typically present with positional dizziness and lightheadedness related to lying on the back.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man who had a sternotomy for valve surgery and reported xiphodynia afterward. The joint involved is shown by the arrow marked region, belongs to which classification of joint?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Synchondrosis:

  • The arrow marked region is xiphi-sternal joint lying between the body of the sternum and the xiphoid process. It is structurally classified as a synchondrosis (primary cartilage joint), and functionally classified as a synarthrosis (immobile joint). It turns into synostosis (bony fusion) in old age.
  • Note: Few authors consider xiphisternal joint as a symphysis.
  • Xiphodynia represents a distinctive syndrome characterized by sternum-related pain and tenderness.

Additional information:

  • Between the ages of 15 and 29, the xiphoid process typically undergoes fusion with the body of the sternum, and turns into synostosis.
  • Ossification of the xiphoid process typically occurs around the age of 40.
  • The xiphoid process sits in the epigastric region of the abdomen and situated at the level of the 9th thoracic vertebra (T9) and corresponds to the T7 dermatome.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Symphysis:

  • Xiphi-sternal joint is a primary cartilaginous joint (synchondrosis).
  • Few authors consider it as a symphysis
  • Manubrio-sternal joint is a symphysis (slightly mobile).

Option C - Syndesmosis:

  • Syndesmosis is a fibrous joint, whereas xiphisternal joint is a primary cartilaginous joint (synchondrosis).

Option D - Synovial:

  • Synovial joints are freely mobile joints, whereas xiphisternal joint is an immobile joint and the type is primary cartilaginous joint (synchondrosis).
  • Rib 2-9 have synovial joints, which are freely mobile and help in pump handle and bucket handle movement in breathing.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding severe acute malnutrition?

1. Weight for length < -3SD

2. Mid-arm circumference > 115mm

3. Applicable to the age group of 6 to 59 months

4. Koilonychia is seen
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1, 3, and 4:

  1. Weight for length < -3SD: A weight-for-length/height z-score (WHZ) below -3 standard deviations (SD) is a criterion for diagnosing severe acute malnutrition (SAM).
  2. Mid-arm circumference > 115mm: This is false. Severe acute malnutrition is diagnosed when the mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is <115 mm.
  3. Applicable to the age group of 6 to 59 months: SAM criteria are generally applied to children in this age range.
  4. Koilonychia is seen: Koilonychia (spoon-shaped nails) can be seen in cases of malnutrition.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: Which of the following non-selective COX inhibitors is considered the drug of choice for treating arthritis and is also used for the closure of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Indomethacin:

  • Indomethacin is a non-selective COX inhibitor that is the drug of choice (DOC) for treating arthritis, including osteoarthritis (OA), rheumatoid arthritis (RA), and reactive arthritis. It is also used for the closure of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Ibuprofen:

  • Ibuprofen is a non-selective COX inhibitor used for various conditions, including the closure of PDA and dental pain, but it is not the DOC for arthritis.

Option C - Mefenamic acid:

  • Mefenamic acid is used primarily for menstrual pain (dysmenorrhea) and is not the DOC for arthritis or PDA closure.

Option D – Naproxen:

  • Naproxen is used as an NSAID and is considered the second most cardio-safe NSAID after aspirin, but it is not the DOC for arthritis or PDA closure.

questions.text: A woman with 6 weeks of amenorrhea presented with vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain. Her pregnancy test is positive, and her HCG level is 2800 IU/L. Where is the gestational sac typically located in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- A (fallopian tube):

  • Given the clinical presentation of 6 weeks of amenorrhea, vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, a positive pregnancy test, and an HCG level of 2800 IU/L, the scenario suggests a possible ectopic pregnancy. In such cases, the gestational sac is most commonly located in the fallopian tube.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are not the most common sites of implantation in ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the device shown below?




	It takes three months to become effective.
	It gives 5 years of intrauterine use.
	Releases 10 mg of intrauterine levonorgestrel daily.
	Amenorrhea and recurrent metrorrhagia are observed as side effects.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1, 2 and 4 are true:

  • The given image shows Mirena IUCD.
  • It is a hormonal IUD that releases about 20 micrograms of levonorgestrel per day.
  • And statements 1, 2 and 4 are an accurate description of the disadvantages of the device.
  • The disadvantages of Mirena IUD include:
    • It may be slightly difficult to insert.
    • It takes 3 months to become effective.
    • Amenorrhea occurs in 20%-25% of cases, which is not desirable in younger women.
    • Ectopic pregnancy is reported in 0.2 per 100 women.
    • Hysterectomy is required in 25% of cases by the end of 3 years due to the recurrence of menorrhagia.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A graph is provided showing an exponential decrease in the plasma concentration of a drug over time. What type of kinetics does this graph represent, and which property is characteristic of this type of elimination?

choices.text: Zero-order kinetics; elimination is constant and independent of plasma concentration.
First-order kinetics; elimination is constant and independent of plasma concentration.
Zero-order kinetics; elimination is directly proportional to plasma concentration.
First-order kinetics; elimination is directly proportional to plasma concentration.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D – First-order kinetics; elimination is directly proportional to plasma concentration:

  • In first-order kinetics, the rate of drug elimination is directly proportional to the plasma concentration of the drug. This results in an exponential decrease in plasma concentration over time, as shown in the graph.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Zero-order kinetics; elimination is constant and independent of plasma concentration:

  • In zero-order kinetics, the rate of drug elimination is constant and does not depend on the plasma concentration. This results in a linear decrease in plasma concentration over time, which is not what is shown in the graph.

Option B - First-order kinetics; elimination is constant and independent of plasma concentration:

  • In first-order kinetics, elimination is not constant and is dependent on the plasma concentration. The rate of elimination changes as the concentration changes, leading to an exponential decrease.

Option C - Zero-order kinetics; elimination is directly proportional to plasma concentration:

  • In zero-order kinetics, elimination is not directly proportional to plasma concentration. Instead, it is constant regardless of concentration.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is transmitted by this vector?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Japanese encephalitis:

  • The image depicts mosquito species: Culex.
  • Option B: JE is transmitted by culex.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Malaria: Malaria is transmitted by anopheles.

Option C - Dengue: Dengue is transmitted by Aedes.

Option D - Brugian filariasis: Mansonia causes Brugian filariasis.

questions.text: Which of the following marked areas represents the time of onset of symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Point C: The area marked as "C” represents the time of onset of symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Point A: The area marked as "A” represents the time of exposure.

Option B - Point B: The area marked as "B” represents the time of pathological changes.

Option D - Point D:The area marked as “D” represents the usual time of diagnosis.

questions.text: A 3-week-old neonate was brought with complaints of forceful, non-bilious vomiting, often presenting after meals. On the barium meal, the string and shoulder sign are seen. What metabolic abnormality is commonly observed with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hyocholeremic metabolic alkalosis:

  • The clinical presentation of forceful, non-bilious vomiting after meals with string sign, i.e., elongated pyloric channel, and shoulder sign, i.e., bulging of pyloric muscle into antrum on barium meals, is suggestive of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.
  • Pyloric stenosis causes persistent vomiting, leading to loss of stomach acid (hydrochloric acid). This results in metabolic alkalosis due to the loss of fluid and hydrogen ions and hypochloremia due to the loss of chloride ions.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: An unimmunized 2-year-old child presented with 6 days of fever and cough, followed by a maculopapular rash on the face and neck on the 4th day. Upon examination, the following finding was observed. What is the nature of the causative virus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Enveloped ssRNA:

  • The clinical presentation and the image showing koplik spots points towards measles infection.
  • Measles is caused by a single-stranded, enveloped RNA virus with 1 serotype. It is classified as a member of the genus Morbillivirus in the Paramyxoviridae family. Humans are the only natural hosts of the measles virus.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: The flow volume curve of a patient is superimposed on a normal flow volume loop. The dotted loop represents the normal curve, while the green loop represents that of the patient. Based on this information, what is the likely disease the patient is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bronchiectasis:

  • The given flow volume loop represents an obstructive lung disease, and among the given options, bronchiectasis is the only obstructive lung disease.

  • Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by obstruction or narrowing of the airways, which makes it difficult for air to flow out of the lungs during exhalation. This results in diminished expiratory flows, meaning that it takes longer for the lungs to empty than normal. (The Expiratory curve shows a scooped-out appearance.)
  • Additionally, due to the air trapping caused by the obstruction, lung volumes, particularly the residual volume (RV) and total lung capacity (TLC), increase, resulting in the shift of the curve to the left (larger volumes).

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and D are restrictive lung diseases, and they usually have decreased TLC and RV. Hence, the flow volume loop of restrictive lung disease is likely to shift to the right (lower volumes).

questions.text: What sample is obtained using this instrument?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bone Marrow Aspirate:

  • The instrument shown in the image is a Klima needle. The Klima needle is a specific type of needle used for bone marrow aspiration. In medical procedures, bone marrow aspiration involves using a needle to withdraw a liquid sample of the bone marrow from the marrow space.

  • Needle is advanced into the marrow cavity with the stylet locked in place.
  • The stylet is then removed, and a syringe is used to aspirate the marrow.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D:

  • The Klima needle is not used for the procedures described in Options A, B, and D. Hence these options are incorrect.
  • Jamshidi needle is commonly used for bone marrow biopsy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for gall bladder carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Smoking:

Smoking is not a risk factor for the carcinoma gall bladder.

  • Risk factors for carcinoma gall bladder are:
    • Choledochal cyst
    • Obesity
    • Gallstone more than 3cm in size
    • Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC)
    • Adenomatous polyp > 10mm
    • Chronic typhoid carrier
    • Porcelain gall bladder

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: What is the recommended course of treatment for mild congenital ptosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Fasanella-Servat operation:

  • Fasanella-Servat operation, aka Tarso-conjunctiva mullerectomy is performed in cases having mild ptosis (1.5 - 2 mm) and good levator function.
  • In it, the upper lid is everted, and the upper tarsal border, along with its attached Muller's muscle and conjunctiva, are resected.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Frontalis Sling operation: Frontalis Sling operation is performed for severe ptosis (4 mm). It involves resection of the frontalis muscle.

Option C - Everbusch’s operation: Everbusch’s operation (skin approach) is done for moderate ptosis (3 mm). It involves the resection of LPS muscle.

Option D - Blaskowic’s operation: Blaskowic’s operation (conjunctival approach) is also done for moderate ptosis (3 mm). It involves the resection of LPS muscle.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male chronic smoker presented with complaints of pain on walking, which subsides by resting. The following finding was seen in addition to the complaints of the patient. What of the following statements are true about this condition?

choices.text: Cessation of smoking will reverse the disease
Amputation will not be required in a non-compliant patient

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Four-limb angiography is the IOC:

  • The clinical presentation of a young patient with intermittent claudication along with Raynaud’s phenomenon seen in the hand of the patient, along with the history of smoking, is suggestive of Buerger’s disease.
  • Four-limb angiography is the gold standard for diagnosing Buerger's disease. It helps identify the site, extent, and severity of the disease. Characteristic collateral known as corkscrew collaterals is seen due to the dilatation of vasa vasorum.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cessation of smoking will reverse the disease: While cessation of smoking is crucial to stop the progression of the disease, it does not reverse the existing damage.

Option C - Large-sized limb arteries are involved: Buerger's disease typically affects small- and medium-sized arteries and thrombophlebitis of superficial or deep veins.

Option D - Amputation will not be required in a non-compliant patient: In patients who continue to smoke or do not comply with other aspects of treatment, the disease can progress, leading to severe ischemia and gangrene, which often necessitates amputation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to the OPD with painful genital ulcers, as shown below. Which of the following can cause a painful ulcer on the glans penis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hemophilus ducreyi:

  • Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. It is characterized by the development of painful genital ulcers, which can occur on the glans penis, shaft, or in the pubic area.

Painful genital ulcer

Painless genital ulcer
  • Chancroid (soft) – Haemophilus ducreyi
  • Herpes simplex virus 2
  • Syphilis – Treponema pallidum
  • Granuloma inguinale – Klebsiella granuolomatis
  • Lymphogranuloma venereum – Chlamydia trachomatis

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl was brought for evaluation for secondary amenorrhea for the past 8 months; her urine pregnancy test (UPT) is negative. Her parents give a history of episodic binge eating and say that she is preoccupied with weight control. Her BMI is 29. Her hand shows the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bulimia Nervosa:

  • The given image demonstrates “Russell's sign” on the patient's right hand.
    Bulimia Nervosa is characterized by recurrent episodes of binge eating followed by inappropriate compensatory behaviors to prevent weight gain, such as self-induced vomiting, laxative or diuretic misuse, fasting, or excessive exercise. Russell's sign, indicated by calluses or abrasions on the knuckles or back of the hand due to repeated self-induced vomiting, is commonly seen in individuals with bulimia nervosa.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anorexia Nervosa: Anorexia Nervosa is characterized by significantly low body weight, intense fear of gaining weight, and a distorted body image. Individuals with anorexia nervosa often restrict their food intake and may engage in excessive exercise.

Option C - Binge Eating Disorder: Binge Eating Disorder involves recurrent episodes of binge eating without compensatory behaviors.

Option D - Night-Eating Syndrome: Night-eating syndrome is characterized by recurrent episodes of night eating, often with a lack of appetite in the morning and an increased appetite in the evening or at night.

questions.text: Which of the following is the choice of inhalational anesthesia in the pediatric age group?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – 4:

  • The preferred method for inducing anesthesia through inhalation in pediatric age is Sevoflurane.
  • It has several advantages, including:
    • Minimal Irritation: It is less pungent and causes less airway irritation compared to other agents.
    • Low Blood-Gas Solubility: Sevoflurane has a low blood-gas partition coefficient, allowing for quick uptake and emergence from anesthesia.
  • The vaporizer of the sevoflurane is marked by a yellow color.
  • Color coding of the vaporizer is as follows:
    • Halothane – Red
    • Isoflurane – Purple
    • Desflurane – Blue

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department with a head injury after a road traffic accident. Post resuscitation of the patient, he is disoriented to the surroundings, and on painful stimuli to his arm, he opens his eyes and withdraws his arm. How do you classify this head injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Moderate:

  • The severity of the head injury can be classified according to the post-resuscitation Glasgow coma score of the patient.
  • According to the given parameters, the Glasgow coma score will be as follows:
    • Eye component: Eye-opening to painful stimuli – 2.
    • Verbal component: Disoriented to the surrounding – 4.
    • Motor component: Withdrawal of the arm to painful stimuli – 4.
  • So, the Glasgow coma score is E2V4M5, which is 10, and a score of 9 to 13 classifies head injury as a moderate head injury.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female presented with complaints of polyuria and polydipsia. Her random blood glucose level is 212mg/dL. What investigations are indicated for this patient?


	ECG
	HbA1c
	Echocardiograph
	Urine ACR
	Fundoscopy
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1, 2, 4, and 5:

  • The patient's presentation and random blood sugar of 212mg/dL points towards a diagnosis of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus.
  • For a newly diagnosed case of type 2 DM, patients should undergo other investigations to check for systemic progression of the disease.
    • HbA1c helps confirm the diagnosis and rule out a random elevation in blood sugar levels.
    • Urine Albumin creatinine ratio is done to check the renal progression of the disease.
    • Dilated fundoscopy should be done at the time of diagnosis to identify and prevent the progression of diabetic retinopathy.
    • ECG is done to rule out resting electrolyte abnormalities and rule out ventricular hypertrophy in cases with co-existing hypertension.
    • ECG is sufficient for cardiac screening and echo is not generally indicated.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation above.

questions.text: Identify the ECG given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Monomorphic Ventricular Tachycardia:

  • The given ECG shows QRS complex tachycardia, but the amplitude of the QRS complexes remains the same with every beat (monomorphic). This is characteristic of monomorphic VT.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Atrial Fibrillation:

  • In atrial fibrillation the ECG will show no visible P waves and an irregularly irregular QRS complex.

Option C - Torsades de Pointes:

  • Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT) also known as torsades de pointes, is characterized by VT with constantly morphing QRS complexes (i.e., the amplitude changes with every beat)

Option D - Ventricular fibrillation:

  • Ventricular fibrillation (VF) is characterized by continuous irregular activation with no discrete QRS complexes. Monomorphic or polymorphic VT may transition to VF in susceptible patients. Cardiac ischemia is the most common cause of VF.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who was recently on menotropin injections for egg harvest presents with breathlessness, abdominal distention, nausea, and vomiting. Her UPT is positive and TVS shows the findings given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS):

  • OHSS is a clinical condition associated with ovarian enlargement due to exogenous gonadotropin therapy (Human menopausal gonadotropin; like menotropin), often used for egg harvest.
  • Symptoms include abdominal pain and distention, ascites, gastrointestinal issues, respiratory distress, oliguria, hemoconcentration, and thromboembolism. It typically occurs during ovulation induction or early pregnancy post-ART.
  • The condition results from increased vascular permeability, causing fluid to shift into the peritoneal cavity. Factors such as high hCG levels and substances like VEGF contribute to its development.
  • Sonographic findings include bilateral enlarged ovaries with multiple cysts and ascites.
  • Management is supportive, focusing on fluid balance, electrolyte monitoring, and possibly thromboembolism prophylaxis.
  • Preventive strategies during ART include tailored gonadotropin dosing and using a GnRH agonist instead of hCG for triggering ovulation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS):

  • Though the USG findings may be similar, it typically presents with chronic menstrual irregularities and hyperandrogenism, not acute symptoms or ascites.

Option B - Ectopic Pregnancy:

  • This may present with abdominal pain and a positive urine pregnancy test (UPT) but without enlarged cystic ovaries and ascites.

Option D - Ovarian Torsion:

  • It presents with acute, severe pelvic pain and possibly an adnexal mass, but not ascites and multiple ovarian cysts as seen in OHSS.

questions.text: Heller's myotomy is performed for____.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Achalasia cardia:

  • Achalasia cardia is a disorder in which the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) fails to relax properly, causing difficulty swallowing. Heller's myotomy involves cutting the muscles at the lower end of the esophagus and cardia to allow easier passage of food into the stomach.
  • Typically, anterior myotomy is performed at least 6 cm proximally at the oesophageal side and 2–3 cm distally into the gastric cardia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy is performed to treat hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

Option C - Esophageal stricture: Esophageal dilatation, stent placement, or surgical resection is performed for esophageal stricture.

Option D - Barret’s esophagus: Radiofrequency ablation or endoscopic resection is performed for Barret's esophagus.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme activities can be estimated in red blood cells to diagnose the vitamin deficiency responsible for Korskakoff syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Transketolase activity:

  • Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder often associated with severe thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, frequently seen in chronic alcoholics.
  • The measure of transketolase activity in RBCs can diagnose thiamine deficiency. Transketolase enzyme needs thiamine pyrophosphate as its coenzyme. If there is a Thiamine deficiency, it will lead to low RBC Transketolase activity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Glutathione reductase: A measure of glutathione reductase is diagnostic of vitamin B2 deficiency as flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), a coenzyme generated from vitamin B2, is needed as a cofactor for the enzyme glutathione reductase.

Option B - Lactate dehydrogenase: Lactate dehydrogenase is involved in the conversion of pyruvate to lactate during anaerobic glycolysis.

Option D – Transaldolase: It is used in the sixth step of the hexose monoshunt pathway to generate glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate and fructose-6-phosphate.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female presented with joint pain and noticeable swelling in her right knee and the metatarsophalangeal joint of her first toe. She has a history of hypertension and was recently prescribed hydrochlorothiazide. She experienced a similar episode a few years ago. Aspiration of her right knee revealed cloudy synovial fluid with an elevated leukocyte count. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Acute Gout:

  • Given the patient's history of similar episodes in the past and the use of hydrochlorothiazide, the likely diagnosis in this case is acute gout due to the use of hydrochlorothiazide.
  • Thiazide diuretics like hydrochlorothiazide are known to increase uric acid levels and precipitate gout attacks, they are to be avoided or used with caution in patients with diabetes, dyslipidemia, hyperuricemia, gout, hypokalemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Septic arthritis:

  • Though septic arthritis also shows cloudy synovial fluid with leukocytosis, it is more common in children and the causative organism (most commonly bacteria) in the synovial fluid can be visualized under a microscope.

Option B- Reactive arthritis:

  • Reiter's syndrome or reactive arthritis is associated with a triad of conjunctivitis, urethritis and arthritis.

Option D- Pseudogout:

  • Pseudogout presents with similar symptoms as gout but usually affects atypical joints like wrist and elbow.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for gastric lavage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Mercury poisoning:

  • Mercury poisoning is not a contraindication for gastric lavage. In cases of heavy metal poisoning, such as mercury, specific chemical antidotes can be used in the lavage fluid to neutralize the toxin. For mercury poisoning, sodium formaldehyde sulphoxylate is used.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are relative contraindications of gastric lavage.

questions.text: Which Vinca alkaloid is associated with the most neurotoxicity but has the least risk of bone marrow suppression?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Vincristine:
