  • It is known for its neurotoxic effects, including peripheral neuropathy, but it has the least risk of bone marrow suppression among Vinca alkaloids.

Incorrect Options:

Option B – Vinblastine:

  • Vinblastine has more side effects related to bone marrow suppression but less neurotoxicity compared to Vincristine.

Option C – Vinorelbine:

  • Vinorelbine is another Vinca alkaloid, but it is not as commonly associated with neurotoxicity or bone marrow suppression as Vincristine or Vinblastine.

Option D – Vinflunine:

  • Vinflunine is a newer Vinca alkaloid used primarily in the treatment of advanced or metastatic urothelial carcinoma and is not typically associated with significant neurotoxicity or bone marrow suppression compared to Vincristine or Vinblastine.

questions.text: The enzyme responsible for regenerating the Vitamin K coenzyme necessary for the synthesis of gamma-carboxy glutamic acid is__________.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Epoxide reductase:

  • Vitamin K epoxide reductase (VKOR) is the enzyme that regenerates the active form of vitamin K (vitamin K hydroquinone) from its epoxide form. This regeneration is crucial for the gamma-carboxylation of glutamate residues on vitamin K-dependent proteins, such as clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X.

Incorrect Options

Option A – Enoyl reductase: Enoyl reductase is an enzyme involved in the fatty acid synthesis pathway. It catalyzes the reduction of enoyl-ACP (acyl carrier protein) to saturated acyl-ACP, which is a key step in the elongation cycle of fatty acid biosynthesis.

Option C - Glutathione reductase: Glutathione reductase is an enzyme that reduces glutathione disulfide back to glutathione. Glutathione is a critical antioxidant that helps protect cells from oxidative damage by neutralizing free radicals and maintains RBC membrane integrity.

Option D – Thioesterase: Thioesterase enzymes hydrolyze thioester bonds in fatty acid biosynthesis and degradation. It helps in releasing fatty acid from the fatty acid synthase complex.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness. He does not report any episodes of gasping at night, but he experiences breathlessness. His BMI is 38 kg/m2, and his blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg. An ABG analysis showed PaO2- 63mmHg and PaCO2- 52mmHg. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome:

  • Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS), aka Pickwickian syndrome, typically occurs in obese individuals who have a body mass index (BMI) greater than 30 kg/m2. This condition is characterized by daytime hypercapnia (elevated PaCO2) and hypoxemia (low PaO2) due to inadequate ventilation.
  • Patients with OHS may present with:
    • Hypercapnia- PaCO2 > 45mmHg
    • Hypoxemia -PaO2< 70mmHg
    • Elevated serum bicarbonate- >27mmHg.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C, and D are incorrect as they show normal ABG reports.

questions.text: Which of the following initiatives is NOT appropriate regarding the Information Technology Updates of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MOHFW)?

choices.text: E-Rakhthkosh: For safe blood donation and blood bank services
Mera Aspataal: A platform for feedback from private and public hospitals.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - M-Cessation: For alcohol cessation:

  • M-Cessation is designed to aid in tobacco cessation, emphasizing public health concerns, not alcohol cessation.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A,C, and D are true regarding the technology Updates of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MOHFW)

Information Technology Updates in MOHFW

  • M- Diabetes: For diabetes primary and secondary protection.

  • E- Rakhthkosh: For safe blood donation and blood bank services.

  • M- Cessation: For tobacco cessation.

  • E- Sanjevani: An online OPD. It started in the year 2019.

  • Mera Aspataal: A platform for feedback from private and public hospitals.

questions.text: A female patient presented with swelling followed by pain near her left knee. The following finding was observed. Which of the following is the most common site of occurrence of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Distal femur:

  • The clinical presentation and radiograph of the knee reveal the soap bubble appearance of the proximal tibia affecting metaphysis is suggestive of giant cell tumor/osteoclastoma.s.
  • The most common site of involvement is the metaphysis of the distal femur and proximal tibia, followed by the distal radius and proximal humerus.

Incorrect Options

Options B, C and D are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a 17-year-old female patient who presented to the OPD after a fall and swelling near the left shoulder joint with the following finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Unicameral bone cyst:

  • The image depicts the left shoulder joint with the shaft of the humerus bone, with a characteristic finding of a well-outlined, lytic, centrally placed meta-diaphyseal lesion expanding and thinning the cortices. A small fracture line and a small fragment are seen within the cavity. The classic ‘fallen leaf/fragment’ sign suggests a unicameral/simple bone cyst.
  • The majority of simple bone cysts occur in the proximal humerus, the proximal femur, or the proximal tibia, most commonly affecting the metaphyseal areas.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. The fallen leaf sign is seen in a unicameral bone cyst.

questions.text: Refsum’s disease is caused by a defect in ____.

choices.text: Beta oxidation of fatty acids in mitochondria
Alpha oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid in peroxisome
Beta oxidation of fatty acids in peroxisome
Alpha oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid in mitochondria

questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Alpha oxidation of branched-chain fatty acid in peroxisome:

  • Refsum disease is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the accumulation of phytanic acid in blood and tissues. This accumulation is due to a defect in the enzyme phytanoyl-CoA hydroxylase, which is responsible for the alpha oxidation of phytanic acid (a branched-chain fatty acid) in peroxisomes.
  • The inability to properly degrade phytanic acid leads to its accumulation, causing various symptoms such as retinitis pigmentosa, peripheral neuropathy, cerebellar ataxia, and ichthyosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Beta oxidation of fatty acids in mitochondria: Defects in beta-oxidation typically lead to mitochondrial medium-chain Acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (MCADD), leading to dicarboxylic aciduria.

Options C and D are incorrect. Refer to Options A and B for an explanation.

questions.text: The letter C in the diagram below represents which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Quadratus femoris:

  • Under the cover of the Gluteus Maximus, a Quadrangular Muscle attached to the femur bone marked as C. is called Quadratus Femoris.

Quadratus femoris:

  • The quadratus femoris is a flat, square-shaped muscle.
  • It is the most inferior of the deep gluteal muscles, located below the Gemelli and obturator internus.
  • Attachments: It originates from the lateral side of the ischial tuberosity and attaches to the quadrate tuberosity on the intertrochanteric crest.
  • Actions: Lateral rotation.
  • Innervation: Nerve to quadratus femoris.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Gluteus minimus:

  • The muscle listed as B is the gluteus minimus.
  • It is involved in weak flexion and medial rotation of the hip.
  • Lateral stabilization of the knee.
  • The superior gluteal nerve supplies it.

Option C - Gluteus medius:

  • The muscle marked as A is the gluteus medius.
  • It abducts and medially rotates the lower limb.
  • During locomotion, it secures the pelvis, preventing the pelvic drop. The superior gluteal nerve supplies it.

Option D - Gluteus maximus:

  • The muscle marked as D is the gluteus maximus.
  • It is the main Extensor of the thigh and assists with lateral rotation.
  • However, it is only used when force is required, such as running or climbing.
  • The inferior gluteal nerve supplies it.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is in accordance with basal cell type breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - ER -ve, PR -ve, HER2 -ve:

questions.text: Which of the following is employed for staging endometriosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Diagnostic laparoscopy:

  • Laparoscopy is considered the gold standard for diagnosing and staging endometriosis. It allows for the detection and diagnosis of pelvic endometriosis, biopsy, and surgical treatment through ablation and removal. During the procedure, a tissue biopsy for validation is also obtained.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are not very helpful in staging the disease.

  • Ultrasound has an 83% sensitivity and 98% specificity but may not pick up small nodules. CT and MRI provide the same information as ultrasound and are not more useful in diagnosing endometriosis.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases does not fall in the category of disease under vision 2020 globally?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Diabetic retinopathy:

  • Diabetic retinopathy is included in diseases under India vision 2020

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and C are incorrect

questions.text: What demographic indicator provides insights into the fertility trends of a country?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - ASFR (Age-Specific Fertility Rate):

  • It measures the number of live births per 1,000 women in specific age groups within a population over a certain period.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - CBR (Crude Birth Rate) , C - TFR (Total Fertility Rate) and D - ASMFR (Age Specific Marital Fertility Rate) does not specifically address fertility trends.

questions.text: What is the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Distichiasis:

  • Distichiasis is a condition in which the eyelashes grow abnormally and emerge from the Meibomian gland openings behind the normal lash line.
  • These extra lashes can cause irritation and damage to the cornea and conjunctiva, leading to symptoms such as eye discomfort, redness, tearing, and sensitivity to light.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Trichiasis: Trichiasis is characterized by inward growth of eyelashes towards the eye, causing them to rub against the cornea or conjunctiva.

Option B – Tylosis: Tylosis is a genetic condition characterized by thickening of the lid margin.

Option C – Madarosis: Madarosis refers to the loss or absence of eyelashes and/or eyebrows.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with a history of seizures. Imaging showed a lesion in the temporal lobe. Based on the characteristic histological features, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Oligodendroglioma:

  • The likely diagnosis in this patient is oligodendroglioma:
  • Oligodendroglioma is a type of brain tumor (glioma) that arises from oligodendrocytes.
  • Most commonly present in the fourth and fifth decades.
  • The lesion is mostly found in the cerebral hemispheres (mainly in the temporal or frontal lobes).

 

  • The tumors are composed of spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm, giving a 'fried egg' appearance.
  • The tumor typically contains a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries ('chicken-wire capillaries).
  • Perineuronal Satellitosis is a feature of oligodendroglioma, it refers to the presence of small, neoplastic cells clustered around neuronal cell bodies.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Glioblastoma:

  • Glioblastoma typically shows areas of necrosis, nuclear atypia, and mitotic activity.
  • "Pseudopalisading" pleomorphic tumor cells with central border areas of necrosis, hemorrhage, and/or microvascular proliferation are seen in this tumor.

Option B - Pilocytic astrocytoma:

  • Pilocytic astrocytoma typically presents with a more compact, less cellular pattern with Rosenthal fibers (Eosinophilic, Corkscrew fibers) and eosinophilic granular bodies.

Option D - Medulloblastoma:

  • Typically, a pediatric tumor located in the cerebellum characterized by densely packed cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and Homer-Wright rosettes

questions.text: Which one of the below-mentioned structures does not pierce the marked structure?

choices.text: Coccygeal branch of the inferior gluteal artery

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Posterior femoral cutaneous nerve:

  • The structure marked in the diagram above is a sacrotuberous ligament, which attaches the pelvis to the vertebral column.
  • The following diagram labels all the structures of the diagram provided in the question:

  • The sacrotuberous ligament extends from the ilium, sacrum, and coccyx to the ischial tuberosity.
  • The posterior femoral cutaneous nerve does not pierce the sacrotuberous ligament. It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen to enter the gluteal region without piercing the sacrotuberous ligament.
  • The sacrotuberous ligament is pierced by coccygeal branches of the inferior gluteal artery, the perforating cutaneous nerve, and branches of the coccygeal plexus.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Coccygeal branch of the inferior gluteal artery:

  • The inferior gluteal artery arises from the internal iliac artery. It gives off a coccygeal branch that pierces the sacrotuberous ligament.

Option B - Perforating cutaneous nerve:

  • The perforating cutaneous nerve (S2, S3) pierces the sacrotuberous ligament and extends to supply the area of the skin over the gluteus maximus.

Option D - Branches of coccygeal plexus:

  • It formed by the S4, S5, and coccygeal root.
  • The anococcygeal nerve arises from the coccygeal plexus and pierces the sacrotuberous ligament to innervate the anal region.

questions.text: Which of the following ions in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is responsible for the resorption of divalent ions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - K+:

  • In the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, the primary ion responsible for the reabsorption of divalent ions, such as calcium (Ca2+) and magnesium (Mg2+), is potassium (K+). The thick ascending limb is impermeable to water but actively transports ions, including sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), and 2 chlorides (Cl-), out of the tubular lumen through the action of sodium-potassium-2 chloride cotransporter (NKCC2) present in the apical membrane of the luminal side of the thick ascending limb (TAL) cell.
  • The other channel in the luminal side of the TAL is the ROMK (Renal Outer-Medullary Potassium) channel, which pushes the absorbed K+ out into the lumen, leaving a positive charge on the lumen called lumen positive charge.
  • Because of this, the positive ions such as Ca2+ and Mg2+ are repulsed into a paracellular pathway (passive reabsorption) through the tight junction and reabsorbed into capillary blood.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presented with complaints of continuous severe epigastric pain radiating to her back for the past 3 days. Upon examination, there is dullness to the percussion on the left side of the chest, and the following sign was observed. What is the investigation of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - CECT:

  • The clinical presentation of continuous severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, dullness to percussion on the left side of the chest suggesting pleural effusion, and the presence of Grey Turner's sign is indicative of acute pancreatitis. Grey Turner's sign (bruising on the flanks) suggests retroperitoneal bleeding, which can be a complication of severe pancreatitis.
  • The investigation of choice for a patient presenting with features of acute pancreatitis is Contrast-enhanced computed tomography. 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D—Serum amylase, Ultrasound, and MRCP are not the investigations of choice for a patient presenting with features of acute pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought with pearly white hemispherical umbilicated papules with a central pore on the inner side of the right thigh. A biopsy of the lesion is shown below. The disease is likely to exhibit which of the following phenomena?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pseudo Koebner phenomenon:

  • The description of the lesion, along with the histopathological image showing Henderson Patterson Bodies, confirms the diagnosis as molluscum contagiosum.

  • Molluscum contagiosum is known to exhibit a pseudo-Koebner phenomenon, where similar lesions develop along the line of trauma due to the microorganism's self-inoculation or seeding.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Reverse Koebner phenomenon: In the "reverse" Koebner response, a lesion resolves when it is traumatized.

Option B - Koebner phenomenon: The isomorphic response is the development of lesions in previously normal skin that has been subjected to trauma. This is seen in psoriasis.

Option D - Isotopic response: The isotopic response involves the occurrence of a dermatosis at the site of a previously healed and unrelated dermatosis.

questions.text: The movement lost on the left gaze, as depicted in the image, is seen in______.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Oculomotor nerve palsy:

  • The image depicts ptosis and limited adduction of the right eye on the left gaze due to weakness of the levator superioris and medial rectus muscle seen in 3rd nerve palsy (oculomotor nerve).

Other signs of oculomotor nerve palsy are:

A - Profound ptosis due to weakness of the levator muscle.

B - Abduction and depression in the primary position due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.

C - Normal abduction as the lateral rectus is intact

D - Limited adduction due to medial rectus weakness.

E - Limited elevation due to weakness of the superior rectus and inferior oblique.

F - Limited depression due to weakness of the inferior rectus.

G - Dilated pupil and defective accommodation due to parasympathetic palsy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Optic nerve damage: Damage to the optic nerve can result in monocular vision loss.

Option B - Trochlear nerve palsy: Trochlear nerve palsy present with vertical diplopia and torsional diplopia with characteristic head posture to the contralateral side.

Option D - Abducens nerve palsy: Abducens nerve palsy is characterized by esotropia in the affected eye with marked limitation of abduction (weakness of lateral rectus muscle) and normal adduction.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident complaining of being unable to dorsiflex and evert the ankle. The following injury was observed on a plain radiograph. Which of the following gait can be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Foot drop gait:

  • The clinical presentation of absent dorsiflexion of the foot and eversion of the ankle in a patient with a history of trauma and radiograph showing fracture of the neck of the fibula is suggestive of injury to the common peroneal nerve.
  • The fracture of the neck of the fibula is the most common cause of common peroneal nerve injury. Inability to evert the ankle after a road traffic accident may lead to a foot drop/stepping gait, involving lifting the foot excessively during the swing phase. This gait abnormality could arise from the impairment of the two evertors (Peroneus longus and brevis) supplied by the superficial peroneal nerve, while the inability to dorsiflex may involve the tibialis anterior supplied by the deep peroneal nerve, prompting the individual to lift the foot higher as a compensatory mechanism.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are not seen in the fracture of the neck of the fibula or common peroneal nerve injury.

questions.text: Which of the following is the reason for the initial rise in arterial blood pressure while performing the Valasalva maneuver?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Increase in aortic pressure:

  • The Valsalva maneuver is a technique used to assess autonomic nervous system function and cardiovascular response.
  • Valsalva maneuver has four phases:

  • Phase I (onset of strain): In this phase, there is a transient increase in blood pressure that lasts for a few seconds. This occurs due to increased intrathoracic pressure adding to the pressure of great vessels like the aorta.
  • Phase II (phase of straining): In this phase, venous return initially decreases, lowering cardiac output and blood pressure for 4 seconds. Later, blood pressure returns to normal due to increased peripheral resistance from sympathetic vasoconstriction. Heart rate steadily increases due to vagal withdrawal and sympathetic activation.
  • Phase III: This phase occurs after the release of strain, characterized by a brief decrease in blood pressure. It is caused by the mechanical displacement of blood to the pulmonary vascular bed due to a decrease in intrathoracic pressure. There is minimal change in heart rate during this phase.
  • Phase IV: Occurs after further release of strain; blood pressure slowly increases, and heart rate decreases for about a minute. This is due to an increase in venous return, stroke volume, and cardiac output.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following is the treatment of choice according to the European Society for Vascular Surgery 2019 guidelines in a patient with the following finding on the CECT abdomen?

choices.text: Observation and repeat imaging in 6 months

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - EVAR:

  • The CECT abdomen of the patient reveals an infrarenal aortic aneurysm in the coronal plane. Blood flowing through the thrombus-containing sac is enhanced with a contrast agent and appears white.
  • According to the European Society for Vascular Surgery (ESVS) 2019 guidelines, endovascular aneurysmal repair is generally recommended as the first-line treatment for patients with infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysms.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Open surgical repair: According to 2020 guidelines published by the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) in the UK, this is the treatment of choice for infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysms.

Option C - Beta-blocker therapy: Beta-blocker therapy is used in patients with cardiovascular disease and is preferred when the risk of mortality is higher by CVS disease than an aneurysm.

Option D is not a modality of treatment.

questions.text: An HIV patient came to the clinic with a long-standing history of diarrhea. Stool microscopy showed the oocysts that were 4-8 μm in size. The image is shown below. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cryptosporidium:

  • Coccidian parasites are responsible for causing chronic diarrhea in an immunocompromised individual (HIV).
  • Cryptosporidium is the most common among coccidian parasites to cause persistent diarrhea. The oocyst with the size of 4-6 μm and an image showing acid fastness confirms the causative parasite to be Cryptosporidium parvum.
  • It is stained with modified acid-fast staining using 0.2%-1% of acid alcohol, showing a pinkish-red color on a uniformly green background.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cyclospora:

  • Cyclospora oocysts on modified acid-fast technique, stain red to reddish-orange, 8-12 μm in size, round, variably acid-fast, contains two sporocysts each bearing sporozoites.

Option C - Isospora:

  • Oocyst of isospora are also acid-fast, but the size of the oocyst is large, i.e., 23-36 μm in size, and is oval in shape.

Option D - Microsporidia:

  • Microsporidia are intracellular parasites characterized by a unicellular spore containing a coiled spring-like tubular polar filament.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic side effect of SGLT-2 inhibitors?

choices.text: Increased risk of urinary tract infections

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Increased risk of urinary tract infections:

  • SGLT-2 inhibitors promote the excretion of glucose in the urine, which can create an environment conducive to bacterial and fungal growth, leading to an increased risk of urinary tract infections (UTIs) and urogenital infections.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Weight gain:

  • SGLT-2 inhibitors are associated with weight loss, not weight gain.

Option C – Hypertension:

  • SGLT-2 inhibitors have antihypertensive effects due to their diuretic action and promotion of sodium excretion, which reduces plasma volume.

Option D – Hypoglycemia:

  • While SGLT-2 inhibitors lower blood glucose levels, they typically do not cause hypoglycemia because their action is dependent on blood glucose levels and they do not stimulate insulin release.

questions.text: The toxin produced by the below given seeds is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pyrrolizidine: 

  • Pyrrolizidine is a toxin linked to Endemic Ascites, which occurs due to contamination of millet seeds with Crotalaria or jhunjhunia seeds.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sanguinarine: Sanguinarine is a toxin associated with Epidemic Dropsy, which results from the contamination of mustard oil with Argemone oil.

Option C - BOAA: BOAA (Beta-oxalylamino-L-alanine) is the toxin that causes NeuroLathyrism, which is associated with the consumption of Khesari dal or Lathyrus sativus.

Option D - Aflatoxin: Aflatoxin is associated with Aflatoxicosis, which results from groundnut, maize, and jowar being infested with Aspergillus flavus or parasiticus.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was brought with complaints of sunburn on minimum exposure to the sun. Upon examination, blisters in sun-exposed areas were observed, with hypo and hyperpigmentation and scaling papules. Which of the following mechanisms is likely to be defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – DNA nucleotide excision repair:

  • The clinical presentation of extreme sensitivity to sunlight, sunburns on minimal exposure, blisters, hypo and hyperpigmentation, and scaling papules is characteristic of Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP).
  • Nucleotide excision repair (NER) is the primary mechanism for repairing bulky DNA lesions, such as those caused by UV radiation, resulting in the formation of thymine dimers, where covalent bonds are formed between adjacent thymine residues. Defects in this repair system lead to conditions like Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP).

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: What is the likely view shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Caldwell’s view:

  • The image shown is characteristic of Caldwell's view (occipitofrontal or nose-forehead view), which is used to visualize the frontal sinus.
  • The view is taken by touching the forehead and nose to the film and X-ray beam projected 15 to 20 caudally, as seen in the image.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Water’s view: It is done to visualize the maxillary sinus, also known as an occipitomental view or nose chin view, in which the nose and chin are touching the film, and an x-ray beam is projected from behind.

Option B - Towne’s view: It is an anteroposterior view with a 30° tilt from above and in front. It shows both petrous pyramids, which can be compared. It is done by acoustic neuroma or apical petrositis.

Option D - Stenver’s view: This view is taken in such a way that the long axis of the petrous bone lies parallel to the film. It is used to demonstrate a petrous pyramid, arcuate eminence, internal auditory meatus, and labyrinth with its vestibule.

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect statement regarding the control of rabies in dogs?

choices.text: If in any community, 50% of the dog population is vaccinated, Rabies can be controlled.
80-90% of the dog population is accessible for vaccination
Dogs should receive primary immunization at the age of 3-4 months and booster doses should be given at regular intervals

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - If in any community, 50% of the dog population is vaccinated, Rabies can be controlled:

  • This is an incorrect characteristic regarding the control of Rabies
  • The correct statement is that if in any community,80% of the dog population is vaccinated, Rabies can be controlled

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C & D these are the correct statements regarding the control of Rabies in dogs.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is an example of a polysaccharide vaccine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pneumococcal vaccine:

  • The Pneumococcal vaccine is an example of a polysaccharide vaccine. Polysaccharide vaccines work by inducing antibody production against the capsular polysaccharides of pathogenic bacteria.
  • It is commonly administered to infants, children, and adults, especially those at increased risk of pneumococcal infections.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hepatitis B vaccine: The Hepatitis B vaccine is an example of a recombinant vaccine prepared using DNA technology and expressed on yeast cells.

Option B - Influenza vaccine: The influenza vaccine is an example of a protein vaccine, consisting of antigens from the influenza virus, including hemagglutinin and neuraminidase.

Option D - Human Papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine: The HPV vaccine is a recombinant vaccine prepared using DNA technology.

questions.text:
Galactomannan test is diagnostic of:


	Invasive aspergillosis
	Systemic candidiasis
	Fusarium verticillioidis
	Mucormycosis
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1 only:

  • Galactomannan is a major polysaccharide constituent of Aspergillus cell walls. The presence of these constituents is diagnostic of Aspergillus.
  • Other pathogens positive for galactomannan are Fusarium, Penicillium, Histoplasma, Blastomyces, and Paecilomyces.
  • Whereas (1,3) b-D glucan is the marker for candida, mucor, and Histoplasma capsulatam.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not diagnosed using Galactomannan test.

questions.text: Which of the following suturing techniques will be preferred for closing skin in a young female patient undergoing thyroidectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – 2:

  • The preferred suturing technique for the closure of skin in thyroidectomy is a subcuticular suture to deal with the cosmetic appearance of a young female.
  • Small bites of the subcuticular tissues are taken at alternate sites of the wound and then gently pulled together to approximate the wound edges, thus avoiding the cross-hatched markings of interrupted sutures.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1: The continuous suture technique involves inserting the first suture in the same way as an interrupted suture, but instead of knotting each stitch individually, the rest of the sutures are inserted in a continuous manner until the end of the wound is reached. This technique is used to close the superficial fascia and skin of the abdomen.

Option C - 3: It is mattress suture. The initial suture is inserted as for an interrupted suture, but then the needle moves either horizontally or vertically and traverses both edges of the wound once again. It is used for the accurate approximation of the irregular depth edges.

Option D – 4: It is interrupted sutures that require the needle to be inserted at right angles to the incision and then to pass through both aspects of the suture line and exit again at right angles. It is done to close the stylohyoid and platysma during thyroidectomy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female presents with eczematous itching lesions. A biopsy revealed a subepidermal cleft with direct immunofluorescence showing Linear C3 & IgG deposition along the basement membrane zone, as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bullous Pemphigoid:

  • A biopsy showing subepidermal split along with linear IgG deposition on direct immunofluorescence is characteristic of Bullous Pemphigoid.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A and D show a “fishnet” pattern on immunofluorescence.

  • Pemphigus vulgaris shows the pattern in the suprabasal area, whereas Pemphigus foliaceus shows the pattern in the stratum corneum.

Option C - Dermatitis herpetiformis: It shows papillary tip immunofluorescence.

questions.text: The barcode sign on the M mode of ultrasound is characteristic of the?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Pneumothorax:

  • In normal lung tissue, the M mode of ultrasound displays a seashore sign. This is characterized by the top part showing the motionless chest wall appearing as parallel horizontal lines and the bottom part showing a sandy or granular pattern because of the lung tissue movement with respiration.
  • When there is a pneumothorax, air accumulates in the pleural space, preventing the lung from expanding and collapsing normally during respiration. This lack of movement means the ultrasound detects only the static, non-moving pleural line, resulting in parallel horizontal lines at the top and bottom of the M mode image, resembling a barcode or stratosphere.

Incorrect Options

Options A, B, and C are incorrect.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child, vaccinated to date, presents to the emergency department with a high fever, severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and drooling of saliva. Upon examination, an inspiratory stridor is observed. A lateral view X-ray of the neck reveals the following finding. The causative organism of the condition is___________.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Streptococcus pneumoniae:

  • The clinical presentation of fever, sore throat, difficulty swallowing, drooling of saliva, inspiratory strider, and x-ray lateral view of the neck revealing thumb sign due to swollen epiglottitis is diagnostic of acute epiglottitis.
  • It is a bacterial infection most commonly caused by streptococcus pneumoniae in a vaccinated child. Whereas in unvaccinated children, hemophilus influenza is the most common cause of acute epiglottitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hemophilus influenza: It was the most common cause of acute epiglottitis in the past due to unvaccinated children against H. influenza.

Options B and C are incorrect: Influenza virus type I and II are the most common cause of croup, aka acute laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis involving the larynx, trachea, and bronchus. It is characterized by a steeple sign in the AP view of the neck due to subglottic stenosis.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures is responsible for endotoxic shock in gram-negative bacteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1:

  • Lipid A is responsible for the endotoxic activity of a gram-negative bacilli.
  • Lipid A is present in the lipopolysaccharide (LPS) layer, which is attached core polysaccharide.
  • The correct labeling of the image is given below:

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 2: It is an O-antigen, a component of lipopolysaccharide (LPS) determining the O antigen specifity.

Option C - 3: It is the outer membrane containing various proteins like porins, which form transmembrane pores that serve as a diffuse channel for small molecules.

Option D - 4: It is the plasma membrane. The plasma membrane contains integral and surface proteins.

questions.text: A liver biopsy is taken from a patient suspected of having Wilson's disease. Which of the following stains will produce a greenish-black color when the sample is stained?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Rubeanic acid:

  • Stains such as rubeanic acid or rhodanine can demonstrate elemental copper. Rubeanic acid gives copper a greenish-black color.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rhodanine stain:

  • Rhodanine stain results in a red to orange-red color in the cytoplasm, indicating the presence of elemental copper.

Option B - Orcein stain:

  • Orcein stain can be used to detect copper-associated protein (CAP), which appears as cola-colored, perinuclear, coarsely granular structures in the cytoplasm.

Option D- Masson trichrome stain:

  • Masson trichrome stain is a histological staining method used to differentiate between various tissue components, mainly collagen (stained blue). It does not specifically target copper.

questions.text: Which of the following is true according to the test performed below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Seen in optic neuritis:
 

  • The image represents the relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), aka, Marcus Gunn pupil characterized by weak pupillary response of the diseased and brisk response by the normal eye seen in incomplete optic nerve lesion (optic neuritis) or severe retinal disease (rhegmatogenous retinal detachment). The difference between the two pupillary reactions is highlighted by the swinging flash test.
  • The image reveals the following findings:
  • Both pupils contract when light is flashed to the right eye, i.e., the normal eye.
  • Both pupils show paradoxical dilatation when light is flashed to the left eye, i.e., showing relative afferent pupillary defect.
  • Both pupils contract when light is flashed to the right eye, i.e., the normal eye.
  • Both pupils show paradoxical dilatation again when the light is flashed to the left eye.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: Which of the following arches contributes most to the pharyngeal arch anomalies?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 2nd pharyngeal arch:

  • 95% of the branchial arch anomalies arise from the 2nd arch.
  • The 2nd arch fistula and sinuses are the commonest of the branchial arch anomalies.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1st pharyngeal arch:

  • Pierre Robin sequence arises from abnormal development of the 1st pharyngeal arch. However, it does not contribute most to the branchial arch anomalies.

Option C - 4th pharyngeal arch:

  • Surgical and medical defects arising from the 4th pharyngeal arch are rare. It does not contribute most to the branchial arch anomalies.

Option D - 5th pharyngeal arch:

  • 5th pharyngeal arch usually regresses after development. No defect is known to arise from this arch.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy develops hypoglycemia after moderate activity. Blood examination reveals raised levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides. On examination, the liver was found to be enlarged. Which of the following deficiencies would be seen in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Glucose-6-phosphatase:

  • The clinical presentation is suggestive of Von Gierke’s disease caused by a deficiency of glucose-1-phosphatase.
  • Von Gierke’s disease is characterized by:
    • Fasting hypoglycemia
    • Doll-like faces - excess triglycerides accumulate in adipose tissue.
    • Xanthomas
    • Ketosis
    • Lactate acidosis
    • Hyperuricemia – due to the breakdown of excessive purines formed due to the accumulation of glucose-6-phosphate.
    • Deposition of glycogen on the liver and kidney will result in organomegaly.

Incorrect Options:

Options A - Alpha-glucosidase: Deficiency of alpha-glucosidase causes Pompe's disease, which is characterized by glycogen storage in lysosomes of the liver, heart, and muscle, leading to cardiomegaly, cardiomyopathy, and floppy baby.

Option C - Muscle phosphorylase: Deficiency of muscle phosphorylase causes McArdle’s disease, characterized by glycogen accumulation in muscle resulting in exercise intolerance only.

Option D - Debranching enzyme: Deficiency of the debranching enzyme causes Cori’s disease, characterized by accumulation of highly branched dextrin in muscles and liver, resulting in hypoglycemia and exercise intolerance.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics is typically associated with a contact rifle wound?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Presence of a muzzle impression:

  • A contact rifle wound is characterized by the presence of a muzzle impression. This occurs because the muzzle of the firearm is very close to the skin when the shot is fired.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Presence of a circular wound:

  • Presence of a circular wound: A contact wound is stellate in shape.

Option B - Absence of burning or blackening: Burning and blackening are present inside the track in contact wounds.

Option D - Absence of abrasion collar: The abrasion collar is present in contact wounds.

questions.text: What is most likely present at the site marked as C in the diagram of 1st rib given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Scalenus anterior:

  • The site marked as C in the diagram shows the scalene tubercle, which is the site of attachment of the anterior scalene muscle. The upper surface of the shaft of the first rib is crossed obliquely by two grooves separated by a ridge. The ridge is enlarged at the inner border of the rib to form a scalene tubercle. The anterior groove on the superior surface of the shaft lodges the subclavian vein(D), and the posterior groove lodges the subclavian artery(B) and the lower trunk of the brachial plexus. Behind the groove for the subclavian artery is an elongated rough area where the middle scalene(A) inserts.
  • The anterior scalene muscle lies beneath the sternocleidomastoid muscle. It originates from the anterior tubercles of transverse processes of C3-C6 vertebrae and attaches to the scalene tubercle present on the medial side of the first rib. Its tendon is sandwiched between the subclavian vein (passing anteriorly) and subclavian artery (passing posteriorly). Both vessels cross over the superior surface of the 1st rib. It elevates the first rib, ipsilateral lateral flexion of the neck and bilateral anterior flexion of the neck and is innervated by the anterior rami of the C5 and C6 vertebrae. The interscalene block is given between the anterior and middle scalene muscles at the level of the cricoid cartilage.

Incorrect Options: 

Option D - Subclavian vein:

  • The site marked as D shows the groove for the subclavian vein. It is an anterior groove on the superior surface of the first rib. The site marked as C shows the scalene tubercle, which is the site of attachment of the anterior scalene muscle.

Option B - Subclavian artery:

  • The site marked as B shows the groove for the subclavian artery. It is a posterior groove on the superior surface of the first rib. It lodges the subclavian artery and the lower trunk of the brachial plexus. The site marked as C shows the scalene tubercle, which is the site of attachment of the anterior scalene muscle.

Option A - Scalenus medius:

  • The site marked as A shows an elongated rough area behind the groove for the subclavian artery. It is the site attachment of the middle scalene muscle. The site marked as C shows the scalene tubercle, which is the site of attachment of the anterior scalene muscle.

questions.text:
A neonate presents with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and periventricular calcifications. Which of the following statements accurately describes the infection?


	Sensory neural hearing loss is a long-term complication.
	20-40% are symptomatic at birth.
	Diagnosis by urine specimen at 5 weeks of age.
	The treatment of choice is ganciclovir
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1 and 4:

  • The clinical presentation of jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and periventricular calcification is suggestive of congenital cytomegalovirus infection.

Statements:

  1. Sensorineural hearing loss is a well-known long-term complication of congenital CMV infection.
  2. Approximately 10-15% of infants with congenital CMV infection are symptomatic at birth.
  3. Detection of cytomegalovirus in urine or saliva is done within the first 4 weeks of life.
  4. Ganciclovir is often used as the treatment of choice for congenital CMV infection, especially in symptomatic neonates with central nervous system involvement.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: According to the myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation, the afferent arterioles contract in response.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Calcium:

  • The myogenic hypothesis suggests that when the afferent arterioles experience an increase in blood pressure or stretch, it triggers the opening of calcium channels in the smooth muscle cells of the arterioles.
  • The influx of calcium ions leads to vasoconstriction, reducing the blood flow and preventing excessive pressure within the glomerulus. This response helps maintain a relatively constant blood flow and glomerular filtration rate despite changes in systemic blood pressure.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A and D are not involved in the myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation.

Option C - Adenosine: Adenosine is a mediator of the tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism of renal autoregulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is a rate-limiting enzyme of bile acid synthesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – 7-a hydroxylase:

  • This enzyme, also known as cholesterol 7α-hydroxylase (CYP7A1), catalyzes the first and rate-limiting step in the classical pathway of bile acid synthesis. It hydroxylates cholesterol at the 7α position, leading to the production of bile acids such as cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - HMG CoA lyase: It is a rate-limiting enzyme of cholesterol synthesis.

Option B - HMG CoA reductase: It is a rate-limiting enzyme of cholesterol synthesis.

Option C - Acetyl CoA carboxylase: It is a rate-limiting enzyme of fatty acid synthesis.

questions.text: Which molecular motor protein results in the spread of the rabies virus from the site of inoculation to the central nervous system?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Dynein:

  • Dynein is a motor protein that facilitates retrograde transport within cells. It moves towards the minus end of microtubules, i.e., retrograde transport, which is typically oriented towards the center of the cell body of the nerve. It transports viruses (rabies), toxins, and growth factors.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Kinesin: Kinesin is an anterograde transport, i.e., positive end-directed molecular motor protein that moves along microtubules, facilitating the transport of vesicles and mitochondria.

Option B and C are incorrect. Myosin is a bi-directional molecular motor protein involved in the transportation of the substance to and from the positive end of the microtubules to the axon terminal with the help of actin.

questions.text: The disease associated with the following finding seen in bone marrow sample is______.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Gaucher disease:

  • The finding associated with the bone marrow sample given in question is crumpled tissue appearance characteristic of Gaucher disease.
  • It is caused by a deficiency of b glucosidase responsible for the degradation of glucocerebroside, leading to the accumulation inside macrophages and giving a typical crumpled tissue appearance, as seen in the image.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are relevant to the BRCA 1 gene:

1) Involved in the repair of double-stranded DNA.

2) Mutation increases the risk of development of ovarian cancer.

3) It is a tumor suppressor gene.

4) Mutation may cause Fanconi anemia in some people.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1, 2, and 3:

  • BRCA 1 and 2 are tumor suppressor genes involved in repairing double-stranded breaks in DNA. Mutations of these genes are implicated in breast cancer. BRCA 1 mutations increase the risk of breast and epithelial ovarian cancer in women.
  • Specific inherited mutations in BRCA2 are associated with Fanconi anemia. BRCA and Fanconi proteins work together in the DNA damage response network. Problems in the BRCA-Fanconi pathway can activate other DNA repair pathways, like the nonhomologous end-joining pathway.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: The following finding was observed in a patient presented with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Renal tuberculosis:

  • The presentation of abdominal pain with sterile pyuria and the finding seen in the radiograph is of a lobulated appearance of the kidney, indicating parenchymal calcification, which is suggestive of the putty kidney.
  • Putty kidney is a characteristic finding seen in renal tuberculosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Medullary Nephrocalcinosis: This condition is characterized by the deposition of calcium salts in the kidney's medulla, often seen in conditions like hyperparathyroidism and renal tubular acidosis. 

Option C - Staghorn calculus: The stag horn calculus is a large triple phosphate stone that takes up the shape of the pelvis and calyces caused by urinary tract infections.

Option D – Chronic kidney disease: It is characterized by a small kidney with thin parenchyma.

questions.text: A patient with a history of acetaminophen poisoning has developed oliguria and deranged liver enzymes. What is used in managing this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - N-acetylcysteine (NAC):

  • NAC is the antidote for paracetamol (acetaminophen) poisoning. It works by replenishing glutathione stores and enhancing the metabolism of N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI), which is a toxic byproduct produced during the metabolism of paracetamol.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pyridoxine:

  • Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) is used as an antidote for isoniazid (INH) poisoning

Option C - Sodium Bicarbonate:

  • Sodium Bicarbonate is used primarily in the management of metabolic acidosis and certain types of drug overdoses (e.g., tricyclic antidepressant overdose) to alkalinize the urine

Option D - Furosemide:

  • Furosemide is a diuretic used to manage fluid overload and hypertension

questions.text: Which of the following is a Third generation Intra uterine device?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 

  • Progestasert is a hormone containing third-generation Intrauterine device.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and D are second-generation copper-containing IUDs.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about the utilization of eFAST?


	Detects free fluid in the abdomen.
	Diagnostic of cardiac tamponade
	Detects fluid > 50 ml accurately
	Solid organ injury is easy to detect
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1 and 2:

  • The extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (eFAST) is a rapid bedside ultrasound examination used primarily in emergency and trauma settings.

Statements:

  1. eFAST is used to quickly identify the presence of free fluid in the peritoneal, pleural, and pericardial cavities.
  2. The eFAST exam can detect pericardial effusion, which, in the context of trauma, can be indicative of cardiac tamponade.
  3. eFAST accurately detects fluid volumes greater than 100 ml, though it is operator-dependent.
  4. eFAST is not particularly sensitive or specific for detecting solid organ injuries; a CT scan is more appropriate.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old male patient presented with difficulty swallowing and severe difficulty breathing. A radiograph was taken, and the following findings were observed. Which of the following surgical approaches will be appropriate for the management?

​​​​​​​
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Sternotomy:

  • The clinical presentation of dysphagia and dyspnea, with a radiograph, shows a large mass predominantly on the left side pushing the trachea to the right side is suggestive of retrosternal goiter.
  • Sternotomy is the choice of surgical approach for large (larger than thoracic inlet) or malignant retrosternal goiter.

  • The blue line shows the deviation of the trachea, and the red line is a large retrosternal goiter.

Incorrect Options:

Options A and B are incorrect. These incisions are not used for the removal of retrosternal goiter.

Option C – Transcervical incision: This is the most common surgical approach to treat small retrosternal goiter.

questions.text: A patient with acromegaly resistant to octreotide therapy is prescribed a GH receptor antagonist that is administered via subcutaneous injection. Which drug has been prescribed, and what is a notable side effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pegvisomant; Visual disturbance:

  • Pegvisomant is a GH receptor antagonist used to treat acromegaly that is resistant to octreotide. It is administered via subcutaneous injection and contains polyethylene glycol (PEG) to make it longer-acting. A notable side effect of Pegvisomant is visual disturbance.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are not GH receptor antagonists.

questions.text: The following finding was observed in a patient who fell on his outstretched hand. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Galeazzi fracture:

  • The X-ray reveals a fracture of the lower one-third radius bone along with disruption of the distal radioulnar joint, typically occurring after a fall on an outstretched hand is characteristic of a Galeazzi fracture.
  • The radius fracture is angulated medially and anteriorly, as seen in the radiograph, and the dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint occurs due to disruption of the interosseous membrane.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Colle's fracture: Colle's fracture is a fracture of the distal radius at its cortico-cancellous junction and may present with dorsal displacement or tilt, and lateral displacement or tilt.

Option C - Rolando's fracture: Rolando's fracture is a T or Y shaped fracture of the base of the thumb, typically resulting from high-energy trauma.

Option D - Monteggia fracture: Monteggia fracture is a fracture of the proximal third of the ulna along with dislocation of the radial head.

questions.text: Identify the structure given:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Spider cell:

  • The entity shown in the image is a spider cell, which is a characteristic feature of rhabdomyoma.
  • Microscopically, they consist of unusually enlarged myocytes with large amounts of glycogen. During routine histologic processing, the glycogen is removed, causing the abundant cytoplasm to appear as thin strands stretching from the nucleus to the surface membrane, creating an appearance known as "spider" cells.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Kupffer cell:

  • Kupffer cells are specialized macrophages found in the hepatic sinusoid along with sinusoidal endothelial cells, Ito cells, and pit cells. They are amoeboid-shaped and attached to the sinusoidal endothelial cells. Their surface contains microvilli, pseudopodia, and lamellipodia, which can project out in all directions.

Option B - Spur cell:

  • Also known as acanthocytes, these are red blood cells with irregular, spiky projections on their surface. They are seen in Abetalipoproteinemia.

Option C - Strap cell:

  • Strap cells are primitive spindle-shaped cells seen in embryonal rhabdomyosarcomas affecting the genitourinary tract.

  • The red arrow shows a strap cell. The white arrow shows a tadpole cell in rhabdomyosarcoma.

questions.text:
Increased pulmonary blood flow will be seen in?

1. Truncus arteriosus

2. Tetralogy of Fallot

3. Transposition of the great arteries (TGA)

4. Ebstein anomaly
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1 and 3:

  • There are 5 types of congenital heart disease, out of which 3 leads to increased pulmonary blood flow. These are as follows.
    1. Transposition of great arteries (TGA)
    2. Truncus arteriosus
    3. Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR)
  • Cyanotic heart diseases decreasing the pulmonary venous return are:
    1. Tricuspid atresia (Ebstein anomaly)
    2. Tetralogy of Fallot.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text:
The pap smear of a 28-year-old woman is given below.



Which of the following is most applicable to cells marked (arrow) in the smear?

choices.text: They are dominant during the estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle

questions.solution:
Correct Option D- They are dominant during pregnancy:

  • The image depicts a normal cervical smear with superficial (pink) and intermediate (blue) exfoliated cervical cells at low power magnification. Superficial cells are dominant during the estrogenic phase, and during the progestogen dominance, like in pregnancy, the basal cells do not mature as effectively as in the estrogenic phase, resulting in a dominance of intermediate cells.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- They are parabasal cells:

  • Parabasal cells are moderately large, with diameters ranging from 15 µm to 30 µm. They have round to oval outlines and dense green cytoplasm. The nuclei occupy about half of the cell. The N/C ratio is approximately 20%, but it can vary. They may be the predominant cell type in atrophic smears from postmenopausal women.

Option B- They are basal cells:

  • Basal cells are small, undifferentiated cells measuring approximately 10–12 µm in diameter. These cells are centrally located around oval nuclei, with fine chromatin and occasional chromocenters and a small delicate amount of cytoplasm.

Option C - They are dominant during the estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle:

  • Superficial squamous cells are large, polygonal cells with delicate, transparent cytoplasm. They measure about 45–50 µm in diameter and have a small, pyknotic nucleus. In Papanicolaou stain, their cytoplasm stains delicate pink and contains keratohyalin granules. The cells also have a small clear halo around the nucleus. The key difference from intermediate cells is the pyknotic chromatin.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on a positive Takayama test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 

  • The Takayama test, also known as the hemochromogen test, is used to confirm the presence of blood. When positive, it produces pink feathery crystals, which are a specific indicator in this test.

Incorrect Options:

Option A -

 

  • This image corresponds to the crystals formed in the Florence test, which detects choline from seminal vesicles, not the Takayama test.

Option B -

  • This image corresponds to the crystals formed in Barberio's test, which detects spermine from the prostate, not the Takayama test.

Option D - 

  • This image corresponds to the crystals formed in the Teichmann test, which produces brown rhombic crystals when identifying hemin crystals, not the Takayama test.

questions.text: How does the resistance in Vessel B differ from the resistance in Vessel A?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Will decrease by 8 times:

  • In the given image, the length and diameter of vessel B are twice that of vessel A.
  • According to the Hagen–Poiseuille equation, resistance can be directly measured by the following formula.
  • R = 8hL/pr4
  • Where,
    • R = resistance.
    • h = viscosity.
    • L = length.
    • r = radius of the vessel.
  • From this equation, the resistance of a vessel is inversely proportional to the fourth power of radius and directly proportional to the length of the vessel.
  • So, if the radius and length are doubled and other parameters remain constant, then the resistance will be:
    • R = L/(r)4.
    • R = 2/(2) 4.
    • R = 2/16 = 1/8.
  • So, the resistance will decrease by 8 times.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old diabetic male presented with complaints of severe pain in the scrotal region for the past 2 days and a history of fever for the past 5 days. Upon examination, there was tenderness, and the following finding was observed:



Which of the following structures will be spared in this case?


	Testis
	Urethra
	Spermatic cord
	Deep fascia
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – 1, 2, and 3:

  • The clinical presentation of fever followed by intense pain and tenderness, along with the clinical picture revealing scrotal swelling suggestive of inflammation and necrotic skin overlying the scrotum in a diabetic patient, is suggestive of Fournier's gangrene.
  • The structures that are usually involved in the Fournier’s gangrene are as follows:
    • Skin
    • Superficial fascia
    • Deep fascia.
  • Structures which are spared are:
    • Urethra
    • Spermatic cord
    • Testis
    • Corpora cavernosa
    • Corpora spongiosa

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.text: A patient is prescribed a single dose of mifepristone 200mg after 55 hrs of unprotected intercourse. Which of the following is relevent to this drug in this context?

choices.text: Blocks the action of progesterone on endometrium

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Blocks the action of progesterone on endometrium:

  • Mifepristone or RU486 is a steroid with an affinity for progesterone receptors. It does not prevent fertilization, but by blocking the action of progesterone on the endometrium, it causes sloughing and shedding of decidua and prevents implantation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Inhibits ovulation:

  • This is the primary mechanism of action for emergency contraceptive pills containing levonorgestrel

Option B - Suppresses LH surge:

  • This is the mechanism of action of ulipristal acetate.

Option D - Prevents fertilization:

  • Mifepristone or RU486 does not prevent fertilization.

questions.text: Single breath nitrogen method is used for measuring _____________
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Anatomical dead space volume:

  • The single breath nitrogen test, aka Fowler’s method, is used to estimate anatomical dead space. It involves inhaling pure oxygen and then exhaling slowly and steadily.
  • The alveolar oxygen is mixed with the nitrogen, whereas the air in the anatomical dead space is free of nitrogen, containing only oxygen, thus measuring the anatomical dead space.
  • Whereas physiological dead space is a sum of anatomical dead space and alveolar dead space and can be measured by the Bohr equation.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Physiological dead space volume: Bohr’s equation is used to measure physiological dead space volume.

Option C - Residual volume: It is calculated by the multiple breath nitrogen washout method.

Option D - Tidal volume: It can be calculated by using a spirometer.

questions.text: An image of the shoulder joint region is given in the figure. Identify the type of epiphyses A, B, and C respectively:

choices.text: A. Atavistic, B. traction and C. pressure
A. Traction, B. atavistic and C. pressure
A. Atavistic, B. aberrant and C. traction
A. Atavistic, B. pressure and C. traction

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - A. Atavistic, B. pressure and C. traction:

Mark A - Coracoid process (Atavistic epiphysis)

  • Atavistic epiphysis is phylogenetically independent but fused to the nearest bone for nutrition seen in:
  • Coracoid process of scapula
  • Os trigonum (talus)

Mark B - Head of humerus (Pressure epiphysis)

  • Pressure epiphysis takes part in the joint formation, is intracapsular. They transmit weight seen in:
  • E.g. Head of the humerus and femur, and condyles of humerus, femur, tibia, etc.

Mark C - Greater tubercle (Traction epiphysis)

  • Traction epiphysis is non-articular and does not take part in weight transmission
  • Appear later than pressure epiphysis seen in
  • Mastoid process
  • Greater and lesser tubercle of the humerus
  • Greater and lesser trochanter of femur

Incorrect Options: 

  • Option A, B & C are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the outer diameter of the Foley catheter shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – 6 mm:

  • The Foley catheter shown in the image with a red color cap is of size 18 Fr (French units).
  • 1 mm = 3 Fr or 1 Fr = 0.33 mm.
  • So, the size of the catheter in mm will be = 18/3 Þ 6 mm.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A pharmacology study measures the dose at which a drug produces toxic effects in 50% of the test population. What is this dose referred to as?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - TD50 (Toxic Dose 50):

  • It is the dose at which a drug produces toxic effects in 50% of the population.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - ED50:

  • ED50 (Effective Dose 50) is the dose at which 50% of the population experiences a therapeutic effect, not toxic effects.

Option B - EC50:

  • EC50 (Effective Concentration 50) is the concentration of a drug that produces 50% of its maximum effect, not related to toxicity or lethality.

Option D - None of the above:

  • This option is incorrect

questions.text: An 8-year-old child with a history of Duchene muscular dystrophy presents to the preop evaluation. Which of the following drugs will be contraindicated as an anesthetic?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Succinylcholine:

  • Succinylcholine is contraindicated in patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy due to the risk of life-threatening hyperkalemia and subsequent cardiac arrest.
  • DMD is associated with muscle weakness and alterations in muscle cell membrane integrity, which can lead to an exaggerated release of potassium when succinylcholine is administered.
  • This can cause severe hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, and potential malignant hyperthermia-like reactions.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

  • These inhalational and local anesthetics are relatively safe and do not produce malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the trotter’s triad?

choices.text: Ipsilateral paralysis of the soft palate
Contralateral paralysis of the soft palate

questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Contralateral paralysis of the soft palate:

  • Trotter's triad is a set of three symptoms typically associated with advanced nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • The components of Trotter's triad include:
    • Conductive hearing loss: Due to eustachian tube obstruction by the tumor, leading to middle ear effusion.
    • Ipsilateral paralysis of the soft palate: Caused by the involvement of cranial nerves X (vagus) by the tumor.
    • Ipsilateral neuralgic pain in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve: Due to tumor invasion or compression of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V), resulting in facial pain on the same side as the tumor.

Incorrect Options

Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following marker denotes lateral recess of the fourth ventricle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - D: 

  • Label D - Fourth ventricle
    • The lateral recess of the fourth ventricle carries CSF towards the foramen of Luschka, where it escapes into the subarachnoid space.

  • A Lateral ventricle lies in the cerebral hemispheres (telencephalon).
  • B - The third ventricle is a midline ventricle in the diencephalon.
  • C - The cerebral aqueduct is a midline ventricle passing through the midbrain (mesencephalon).
  • D - Fourth ventricle The lateral recess of the fourth ventricle carries CSF towards the foramen of Luschka, where it escapes into the subarachnoid space.

  • The lateral recess is the projection of the fourth ventricle, which extends into the inferior cerebellar peduncle of the brainstem.
  • The lateral opening is the end of the lateral recess.
  • The vestibular area and the cochlear nuclei may be found in the lateral recess area.
  • The fourth ventricle has a clinical correlation with hydrocephalus and medulla blastoma.

Incorrect Options: 

  • Option A, B & C are incorrect.

Label A: Lateral ventricle

  • Lying in the cerebral hemispheres (telencephalon).
  • It is a C-shaped cavity present in the deep cerebrum.
  • It contains cerebrospinal fluid.

Label B: The third ventricle

  • The third ventricle is a midline ventricle in the diencephalon.
  • It is a narrow funnel-shaped cavity present in the midline between two diencephalon hemispheres.

Label C: Cerebral aqueduct

  • The cerebral aqueduct is a midline ventricle passing through the midbrain (mesencephalon).

questions.text: A newborn baby was brought to the OPD with a characteristic complaint of burnt sugar smell of urine. The likely defect to be seen is.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase:

  • Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) is a metabolic disorder caused by a defect in the branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase complex (BCKDH), which is responsible for the catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine). When this enzyme complex is defective, the corresponding keto acids accumulate and are excreted in the urine, giving it a characteristic sweet, burnt sugar smell.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Debranching enzyme: This enzyme is involved in glycogen breakdown, and its deficiency leads to glycogen storage diseases such as Cori’s disease, characterized by hypoglycemia and exercise intolerance.

Option B - Branched-chain amino acid: While branched-chain amino acids are involved in the disease, the defect is specifically in the enzyme that metabolizes them, i.e., branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase complex.

Option D - Branching enzyme: This enzyme is involved in glycogen synthesis, and its deficiency leads to Andersen's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with VAPP (vaccine-associated paralytic polio)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Wpv3:

  • Wild poliovirus type 3 (wpv3) is associated with Vaccine-Associated Paralytic Polio (VAPP), but it does not cause outbreaks.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and D

  • Wild poliovirus type 2 (wpv2) in the trivalent Oral Poliovirus Vaccine (tOPV) led to the emergence of Circulating Vaccine-Derived Poliovirus (CVDPV), which caused dangerous outbreaks.
  • Vaccine-derived poliovirus (VDPV) includes CVDPV (circulating), AVDPV (ambiguous), and IVDPV (immunodeficient).
  • wpv2 was eradicated in September 2015, while wpv3 was eradicated in October 2019.
  • There is no Wpv4

questions.text: In the context of primary health care principles, which aspect exemplifies the involvement of local community members in health initiatives such as the recruitment of ASHA workers?"
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Community participation:

  • The recruitment of ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) workers involves engaging members of the local community to participate actively in healthcare delivery.

  • ASHA workers are community health workers chosen from within the community itself, reflecting the principle of community participation in primary health care.

  • This principle emphasizes the importance of involving individuals and communities in decision-making processes concerning their health needs and services.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B, and D are incorrect. These are not directly related to the concept of community participation in primary health care.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for prophylaxis of rheumatic fever, administered at a dose of 1.2 million IU once a month?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Benzathine penicillin:

  • It is the drug of choice for prophylaxis of rheumatic fever, given at a dose of 1.2 million IU once a month.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Amoxicillin:

  • Amoxicillin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic but is not typically used for prophylaxis of rheumatic fever.

Option C – Ceftriaxone:

  • Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin and is not used for prophylaxis of rheumatic fever.

Option D – Azithromycin:

Azithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic and is not the drug of choice for prophylaxis of rheumatic fever.

questions.text: Which of the following lymph nodes drains the lateral aspect of the mammary gland?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Pectoral lymph nodes:

  • The breast is surrounded by many lymph nodes like axillary lymph nodes, internal mammary lymph nodes, supraclavicular lymph nodes, posterior intercostal lymph nodes, and subdiaphragmatic lymph nodes.
  • About 75% of the lymph from the breast drains into the axillary lymph nodes.
  • About 20% of the lymph from the breast drains into internal mammary lymph nodes, and the last 5% of lymph drains into posterior intercostal lymph nodes.
  • The anterior lymph nodes, also called pectoral lymph nodes, drain the lateral part of the breast.
  • Anterior axillary lymph node
  • Along the lateral thoracic vein
  • On the anterior wall of axilla on pectoral muscle
  • Drains the lateral aspect of the mammary gland

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Subscapular lymph nodes:

  • Subscapular lymph nodes are also known as posterior lymph nodes.
  • These lymph nodes are present on the posterior wall of the axilla along the inferior border of the subscapularis muscle.
  • They mainly receive the lymph from the posterior thoracic wall and drain into the Central and Apical nodes.

Option B - Humeral lymph nodes:

  • Human lymph nodes are also known as lateral lymph nodes.
  • Lateral lymph nodes receive the lymph from the arms and drain it into the deep cervical, apical and Central cervical lymph nodes.

Option C - Parasternal lymph nodes:

  • Parasternal lymph nodes are also known as sternal glands.
  • They are present in the intercostal spaces (at the anterior ends).
  • Drains medial aspect of mammary gland

questions.text: The given USG is indicative of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Molar pregnancy:

  • The ultrasound shows an enlarged uterus with heterogeneous multicystic areas, giving a snowstorm appearance. The findings are suggestive of gestational trophoblastic disease/molar pregnancy; choriocarcinoma cannot be entirely excluded.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tubal ectopic:

  • Tubal ectopics are known to show a “ring of fire” sign on TVS color Doppler. This ring of fire or ring of vascularity signifies a hypervascular lesion with peripheral vascularity.

Option B - Intrauterine death:

  • IUD on USG is likely to show Spalding sign. The Spalding sign refers to the overlapping of the fetal skull bones caused by the collapse of the fetal brain. It usually appears a week or more after fetal demise in utero.

Option D - Adenomyosis:

  • Adenomyosis is likely to show a “shutter blind” effect or “venetian curtain sign” on USG. This effect is believed to indicate the invasion of endometrial glands into the sub endometrial tissue, manifesting as echogenic linear striations.

questions.text: A patient presents with a painless mass on the floor of the mouth, as shown in the image below. What is the definitive treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Removal of submandibular gland:

  • The image shows a characteristic bluish swelling in the anterior floor of the mouth, which resembles the belly or air sac of a frog. This is diagnostic of a sublingual ranula.
  • Treatment of a sublingual ranula should include removal of the sublingual gland, as this gland has multiple ducts, and ranulas can recur if the gland is left behind.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D individually have not been proven to be definitive management solutions.

  • The success rates for treating ranulas with incision, drainage, and marsupialization are low.
  • Though Botulinum toxin injections into the ranula and the sublingual gland have shown promising results, they need further evaluation.

questions.text: Which of the following marked nerves supplies the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle, the only abductor of vocal cords?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - C: 

  • C marks the recurrent laryngeal nerve. The Posterior Cricoarytenoid muscle is supplied by the internal laryngeal nerve, a terminal branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve.
  • Posterior cricoarytenoid is the only abductor of vocal cords. It is a life-saving muscle.

Nerves of Larynx:

  • The Vagus nerve (10th cranial nerve) supplies the entire larynx through its branches.

Superior laryngeal nerve

  • It originates from the vagus nerve approximately 2.5cm below the base of the skull. It divides to give external and internal branches.
  • The internal laryngeal nerve provides autonomic and sensory supply to the mucosa superior to the glottis.
  • The external laryngeal nerve gives motor innervation and visceral efferent fibres to the cricothyroid muscle. The Cricothyroid is the only muscle in the larynx not supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.
  • Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (RLN)
  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve differs in its origin and course on both sides of the body. The right RLN arises anterior to the first part of the subclavian artery and arches around it to ascend behind it. It crosses the inferior thyroid artery at the lower pole of the thyroid gland. On the other hand, Left RLN arises at the left of the aortic arch, passes below it, and ascends along the trachea.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - A:

  • A- Cervical sympathetic chain
  • The cervical sympathetic chain is a part of the autonomic nervous system and provides sympathetic fibres to various viscera.
  • The cervical sympathetic chain may be compressed by Pancoast tumor and results in the classic triad of Horner’s Syndrome:
  • Partial ptosis
  • Miosis
  • Anhydrosis

Option B - B:

  • B- Denotes Vagus nerve
  • It would be more appropriate to pick a more specific option of the recurrent laryngeal nerve rather than the vagus nerve.

Option D - D:

  • The point towards D depicts phrenic nerve
  • The phrenic nerve supplies the diaphragm, and its injury can compromise respiratory movements and can cause paralysis of the ipsilateral hemidiaphragm. Bilateral injury can lead to complete paralysis of the diaphragm and may require mechanical ventilation.
  • The phrenic nerve is a branch of the cervical plexus that contains motor and sensory fibres but no cutaneous nerve fibres.
  • The phrenic nerve is identified as running anterior to the scalenus anterior muscle.

questions.text: In a study evaluating the performance characteristics of a diagnostic test, a receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve was constructed. The X-axis of the ROC curve represents which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - True positives:

  • The X-axis of a receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve typically represents the false positive rate (FPR), which is calculated as the number of false positives divided by the sum of true negatives and false positives.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A,C and D are incorrect due to the above given reasons

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a farmer who has a wart-like skin growth on his foot, and the following finding was observed on histopathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Chromoblastomycosis:

  • The clinical presentation of warty growth on the foot of a farmer with histopathological finding of copper penny, aka sclerotic bodies, is consistent with the diagnosis of chromoblastomycosis, aka verrucous dermatitis (cauliflower-like wart).

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Mycetoma: Mycetoma presents with multiple discharging sinuses on the foot. It shows sunray appearance on histopathology.

Option C - Sporotrichosis: It is caused by Sporothrix Schenckii. Histopathological examination shows asteroid bodies.
