Option D—Blastomycosis: It is caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis and is characterized by a figure of 8 appearance on staining.

questions.text: The following X-ray finding was observed in a child with a history of foreign-body ingestion. Identify the foreign body ingested.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Button battery:

  • An AP view of the X-ray reveals a button battery that has a bilaminar structure, making it appear as a double-ring or halo on plain radiographs.
  • The double-ring shadow helps to differentiate battery from coin ingestions.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Coin: A coin appears as a round, uniform, and dense object with smooth, even edges.

Options B and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: The lung specimen from an autopsy is displayed below. What is the most likely risk factor associated with this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Asbestos exposure:

  • The image shows a thick, firm, white pleural tumor tissue that ensheathes the lung. This is indicative of malignant mesothelioma.
  • The most important risk factor for mesothelioma is asbestos exposure.
  • Asbestos fibers are mineral fibers that irritate the pleura when inhaled. Their long and thin structure is particularly hazardous as it facilitates penetration of the lung tissue, causing repeated injury to the mesothelial cells lining the pleura. Asbestos fibers disrupt mitosis by severing the mitotic spindles, resulting in aneuploidy.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following autoimmune diseases show the given pattern in the ANA study?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Systemic sclerosis:

  • The given image shows a nucleolar pattern of staining on the ANA test. Systemic sclerosis is most likely to show a nucleolar pattern of staining.
  • The nucleolar pattern is associated with homogeneous or speckled staining of the nucleoli, along with weak speckled or homogeneous staining of the nucleoplasm. These patterns are associated with anti-RNA polymerase III, anti-fibrillarin, anti-Th/To, and anti-PM/Scl antibodies.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Systemic Lupus Erythematosus: ANA patterns in SLE are typically homogeneous, speckled, or rim (peripheral) patterns.

Option C - Dermatomyositis: ANA patterns in dermatomyositis are usually speckled.

Option D - Primary biliary cirrhosis: Primary biliary cirrhosis often displays a centromeric or punctate nuclear envelope pattern in ANA testing.

questions.text: Which of the following is the main mechanism of action of Theophylline in the treatment of asthma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Phosphodiesterase 4 inhibition:

  • The main mechanism of action of theophylline in asthma is as a phosphodiesterase 4 (PDE-4) inhibitor. By inhibiting PDE-4, theophylline increases the levels of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP), leading to bronchodilation.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C- They are also the mechanism of action of theophylline but are not the main mechanisms that contributes to its therapeutic effects in a patient with asthma.

questions.text: Which of the following methods of estimation of burn is most accurate in the pediatric age group?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lund-Browder chart:

  • The Lund-Browder chart is the most accurate method for estimating (total percentage of body surface area) TBSA for children. Children have proportionally larger heads and smaller lower extremities, so the total percentage of body surface area is more accurately estimated using the Lund-Browder chart.

Incorrect Options:​​​​​​

Option B - Rule of 9s: It is the most efficient method of to estimate total percentage of body surface area in adults.

Option C - Berkow’s formula: This method is also involved in the estimation of TBSA in adults and children, but it is not the most accurate.

Option D - Palm method: Small or patchy burns can be approximated by using the surface area of the patient's palm.

questions.text: The below given instrument/device helps measure which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Air temperature:

  • A Stevenson screen is a type of shelter used in meteorology to house instruments that measure air temperature.
  • It is typically a white, louvered wooden box with double walls and a slanted roof.
  • This design helps protect the instruments inside from direct sunlight, precipitation, and other sources of interference that could affect their readings.
  • The louvered sides allow for ventilation, ensuring that air can freely circulate around the instruments while preventing direct exposure to sunlight.
  • This helps provide more accurate and representative measurements of the surrounding atmospheric conditions.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Air velocity:

  • Air velocity is commonly measured using instruments called anemometers.
  • Several types of anemometers measure wind speed and direction.

Option C - Atmospheric pressure:

  • Atmospheric pressure is commonly measured using a device called a barometer.
  • There are different types of barometers, but the most common is the mercury barometer.

Option D - Amount of sunlight absorbed:

  • The amount of sunlight absorbed by a surface or material can be measured using various instruments and techniques.
  • One common method is using a solar photometer or spectrophotometer, which measures the intensity of sunlight at specific wavelengths before and after it passes through or interacts with the material of interest.

questions.text: Which of the following gastrointestinal complications is commonly associated with enteral feeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Abdominal cramps:

The complications of enteral feeding are divided into three main categories:

Tube-related Complications:

  • Malposition.
  • Displacement.
  • Blockage.
  • Breakage/leakage.
  • Local complications: Erosion or irritation of the skin or mucosa at the site of tube insertion.

Gastrointestinal Complications:

  • Diarrhoea.
  • Bloating, nausea, vomiting.
  • Abdominal cramps.
  • Aspiration.
  • Constipation.

Metabolic/Biochemical Complications:

  • Electrolyte disorders, including refeeding syndrome
  • Vitamin, mineral, and trace element deficiencies
  • Drug interactions.

Incorrect Options:

Options A and D are considered Metabolic/Biochemical Complications of enteral feeding.

Option B - Malposition: Malposition is a tube-related complication of enteral feeding.

questions.text: Which of the following feature is true regarding the given CTG:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - CTG shows variable decelerations:

  • Variable decelerations have variable onset, duration, and depth. They may occur with contractions or between contractions. Typically, they have an abrupt onset and rapid recovery, in contrast to other types of decelerations that gradually slow and recover.

  • They are believed to be a response to umbilical cord compression. If the cord is only slightly compressed, it can obstruct the umbilical vein, leading to a decrease in oxygen supply and a compensatory increase in heart rate. When this increase is followed by a major drop in heart rate, it is called a "shoulder" phenomenon.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - CTG shows tachycardia:

  • Tachycardia is the sustained elevation of fetal heart rate baseline above a 160 BPM. Tachycardia can be a normal response to some increased need for oxygen. For example, increased fetal activity and maternal fever.

Option C - CTG shows early decelerations:

  • Early decelerations are periodic slowing of the fetal heartbeat, which are synchronized exactly with the contractions. These dips are rarely more than 20 beats per minute below the baseline. These innocent changes are thought to be due, in many cases, to fetal head compression within the birth canal.

Option D - CTG shows late decelerations:

  • Late decelerations are repetitive, gradual decelerations of the fetal heartbeat occurring after the peak of the contraction. They are indicative of potential uteroplacental insufficiency.

questions.text: A 48-year-old presents with nasal obstruction, purulent nasal discharge, and a widening of the nasal pyramid. A biopsy of the nose revealed the following finding in Warthin-starry stain. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Rhinoscleroma:

  • The clinical presentation of nasal obstruction, purulent nasal discharge, and widening of the nasal pyramid with biopsy showing Mikulicz cell is suggestive of rhinocleroma.
  • It is a chronic granulomatous bacterial infection of the nose caused by Klebsiella granulomatis.
  • Mikulicz cells are large, foamy macrophages containing the causative bacteria, i.e., gram-negative bacilli, as seen in the image, are typically seen in rhinoscleroma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Rhinosporidiosis: It is caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, an aquatic protozoan characterized by polypoid lesions with sporangia seen on histopathology.

Option C - Tuberculosis of nose: It presents with granulomas and caseating necrosis, with acid-fast bacilli in Ziehl-Neelsen staining, and commonly affects the nasal septum.

Option D – Leprosy: It is caused by Mycobacterium diagnosed by acid-fast bacilli in tissue samples and characterized by saddle nose deformity and alar retrusion known as leprae nose.

questions.text: Identify the lines shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Blaschko’s lines:

  • The lines in the image represent Blaschko lines. Unlike Langer’s lines, Blaschko's lines show an inverted U shape over the breast area and a V shape over the upper spine. They also show spiraling over the scalp.
  • Blaschko’s lines are lines of normal developmental patterns. They do not follow any known nervous, vascular, or lymphatic structures in the skin. Certain conditions, like pigmentary mosaicism, follow Blaschko’s lines.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Marionette lines: Melomental folds, also known as marionette lines, are a result of facial aging. These curvilinear wrinkles are caused by facial movements and the aging process, and they extend downward from the corners of the mouth.

 

Option B - Langer's lines: Langer's lines, also known as cleavage lines, depict the natural orientation of collagen fibers in the skin. These lines show the direction of tension and elasticity in the skin. When surgical incisions are made parallel to Langer's lines, the wound edges align with the natural tension lines, leading to improved wound healing and minimal scarring.

Option C - Epidermal ridges: Epidermal ridges, also known as fingerprints, are unique patterns formed by the arrangement of the epidermis on the fingertips. They play a role in grip and tactile sensation.

questions.text: A newborn is hypermetropic by______.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - + 2.5 D:

  • Hypermetropia refers to a refractive error where the eye has difficulty focusing on near objects.
  • In newborns, a certain degree of hypermetropia is considered normal. A refractive error of +2.5 D to 3.0 D is within the expected range for a newborn.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presented with incoherent speech and impaired comprehension. He can speak fluently but with errors and unnecessary wordiness. Despite this, the patient can perform commands like closing and opening eyes and sitting up from a lying down position. Given that he is a right-handed individual, what is the probable site of embolic occlusion in this case?

choices.text: Left superior branch of middle cerebral artery
Right superior branch of middle cerebral artery
Left inferior branch of middle cerebral artery
Right inferior branch of middle cerebral artery

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Left inferior branch of middle cerebral artery:

  • The patient's presentation of fluent but nonsensical speech, impaired comprehension, and the ability to follow simple commands without difficulty points towards Wernicke’s aphasia. Given that he is right-handed, the dominant hemisphere for language is typically the left hemisphere.
  • Wernicke's aphasia is associated with damage to the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus, typically caused by embolic occlusion of the inferior division of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplying the temporal cortex of the dominant hemisphere.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Left superior branch of middle cerebral artery: An occlusion in this vessel results in Broca's aphasia (nonfluent aphasia) and right hemiparesis.

Option B - Right Superior Branch of MCA: An occlusion in this vessel results in Left hemiparesis and hemineglect (if the right hemisphere is nondominant)

Option D - Right Inferior Branch of MCA: An occlusion in this vessel results in hemineglect or spatial agnosia (if the right hemisphere is nondominant) and left superior quadrantanopia.

questions.text: Which of the following occupational exposures typically require daily post-placement examinations?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Dichromate industries:

  • Dichromates are highly toxic compounds commonly used in industrial processes. Due to their acute toxicity and potential for rapid onset of symptoms, daily post-placement examinations are often necessary to promptly detect and address any adverse health effects resulting from exposure.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and C examinations are done on monthly basis.

questions.text: A woman, pregnant with a single fetus who has had 2 sets of twins previously, is due in 4 weeks. Given that one set of twins is alive and well, and 1 twin of the second set was stillborn, what is her obstetric score?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - G3P2L3:

  • The obstetric score of a pregnant woman who has previously delivered two sets of twins would be G3P2L3.
  • Gravidity: (G) denotes the total number of pregnancies a woman has had, including the current one. It is irrespective of the period of gestation.
  • Parity: (P) denotes the total number of previous deliveries crossing the period of viability. (28 weeks). It includes both live and stillbirths but does not include the current pregnancy.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which drug is the patient most likely receiving if they develop symptoms seen in the given picture and hypotension during administration?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Vancomycin:

  • The symptoms described in the picture, including flushing on the face, red-colored rashes, and hypotension, are indicative of Red man syndrome.
  • Red man syndrome is a hypersensitivity reaction associated with rapid intravenous infusion of Vancomycin, causing histamine release from mast cells.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D: These symptoms are not associated with the use of Amoxicillin, Ciprofloxacin, or Gentamicin.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant was brought to the hospital after a sudden and unexplained death. To determine the cause of death, a postmortem examination is needed. Given the case, which postmortem technique is most appropriate to perform?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Rokitansky Method:

  • The Rokitansky or the In-situ method is used for dissecting bodies with suspicion of highly transmissible diseases and is specifically recommended for infants under one year of age.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are not preferred in infants under one year of age.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a perineal approach for the management of full-thickness rectal prolapse?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Frykman Goldberg’s rectopexy:

  • Frykman Goldberg’s procedure is not a perineal approach for the management of full-thickness rectal prolapse. Instead, it is an abdominal approach-based rectopexy.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C: They are perineal approaches for the management of full-thickness rectal prolapse.

questions.text: Adalimumab is planned to be initiated for a patient with rheumatoid arthritis. Which screening test is an absolute indication in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Tuberculosis screening:

  • The patient has to be screened for latent tuberculosis.
  • The body's defense against mycobacteria depends on the granulomatous response, which involves isolating the bacteria within granulomas. TNF-alpha is essential for recruiting cells and the functioning of the granuloma, as well as for the ability of macrophages to contain the growth of tuberculosis bacteria inside cells. This process is affected when using TNF-alpha inhibitors such as adalimumab.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Viral hepatitis panel:

  • This is indicated for initiation of drugs like Methotrexate, Leflunomide, and Rituximab due to its hepatotoxic potential and potential reactivation of hepatitis B.

Option B - G6PD level:

  • This is indicated in Sulfasalazine, as it can precipitate hemolysis in individuals with G6PD deficiency.

Option C - CBC with differential:

  • This is indicated in Methotrexate, Leflunomide, Anakinra, and Tocilizumab

questions.text: The given condition is ______
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Trophic ulcer:

  • Trophic ulcers, also known as neuropathic ulcers, caused by impaired nutrition, defective blood supply, neurologic deficit, pressure, anemia, and decreased sensation due to an underlying cause like diabetes, leprosy, peripheral neuritis, and paraplegia may lead to the development of trophic ulcers.
  • They typically present with a punched-out lesion, as seen in the image, often seen in weight-bearing areas where pressure or friction commonly occurs.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Tuberculous ulcer: Tuberculous ulcer is characterized by undermined edges.

Option B – Venous ulcer: These ulcers often occur due to venous insufficiency, typically found on the lower leg, just above the ankle. They are painful in the early stages and often have sloping edges.

Option D – Rodent ulcer: Rodent ulcer is a malignant ulcer (basal cell carcinoma) and has raised and beaded edges often seen on the face.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is brought with fever, headache, and photophobia that progressed to disorientation. Her blood investigations showed anemia with decreased platelet count, elevated serum creatinine, and BUN. Her peripheral smear showed a considerable number of fragmented RBCs. Which of the following is not traditionally incorporated in her treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Eculizumab:

  • Given the presentation and laboratory findings, including the peripheral smear showing schistocytes, the likely diagnosis is thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).
  • Eculizumab is used in the treatment of Atypical HUS (aHUS). aHUS is typically caused by genetic defects in complement genes or antibodies targeting complementary regulatory proteins, leading to persistent complement activation. Eculizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against C5.
  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is primarily treated with plasma exchange (plasmapheresis) and immunosuppressive therapy such as corticosteroids (e.g., methylprednisolone) and rituximab, which target autoantibody-producing B cells. Caplacizumab, another monoclonal antibody, is also used specifically in the treatment of acquired TTP.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D are typically used in the treatment of TTP, as explained above.

questions.text: Which of the following second messengers is responsible for the activation of enzyme protein kinase C?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Diacylglycerol:

  • Diacylglycerol (DAG) is a lipid-derived second messenger that remains in the cell membrane. It is produced from the hydrolysis of phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate by the action of phospholipase C.
  • Diacylglycerol activates the enzyme protein kinase C, leading to phosphorylation and action of the hormone.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Inositol triphosphate: Inositol 1,4,5-triphosphate (IP3) is another product produced by phospholipase C. IP3 mobilizes calcium ions from mitochondria, and the endoplasmic reticulum, and leads to cell response such as smooth muscle contraction.

Option C – cAMP: Cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) is a second messenger derived from ATP by the action of adenylate cyclase. It activates cAMP-dependent protein kinase A (PKA).

Option D - cGMP: Cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) is another second messenger involved in signalling pathways, such as those regulating vasodilation. It activates cGMP-dependent protein kinase G (PKG).

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Ketoconazole is correct?

choices.text: It is primarily used as a first-line treatment for systemic fungal infections.
It has minimal hepatic toxicity compared to other azole antifungals.
Ketoconazole inhibits CYP enzymes, leading to reduced synthesis of steroid hormones.
It is the drug of choice for the treatment of invasive candidiasis.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Ketoconazole:

  • It is known for its maximum CYP inhibiting action, which results in the inhibition of steroid hormone synthesis. This can lead to adverse effects such as adrenal insufficiency, reduced testosterone levels causing gynecomastia and impotence, and menstrual irregularities due to decreased estrogen synthesis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It is primarily used as a first-line treatment for systemic fungal infections:

  • Ketoconazole is rarely used nowadays and is not considered a first-line treatment for systemic fungal infections due to its high toxicity and availability of safer alternatives.

Option B - It has minimal hepatic toxicity compared to other azole antifungals:

  • Ketoconazole is actually considered the most hepatotoxic azole antifungal and is rarely used systemically due to this risk.

Option D - It is the drug of choice for the treatment of invasive candidiasis.

  • Ketoconazole is not typically the drug of choice for invasive candidiasis due to its limited efficacy and significant adverse effects.

questions.text: A 3-month-old male infant with no significant medical history is found unresponsive in his crib in the early morning hours. The parents are smokers, and the infant was born prematurely. Autopsy reveals cyanosis of the face and petechial hemorrhages in organs but no other significant findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B - Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS):

  • Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) is the unexpected and unexplained death of an otherwise healthy infant, typically during sleep. Key factors associated with SIDS include prematurity, parental smoking, and finding the infant unresponsive in the crib. The autopsy findings of cyanosis of the face and petechial hemorrhages in organs without other significant findings are also seen in SIDS.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Caffey Kempe syndrome:

  • Caffey Kempe syndrome, also known as battered baby syndrome, is likely to show patterned bruises, burns, tears inside the upper lip near the frenulum, and retinal hemorrhage.

Option C - Munchausen Syndrome by Proxy:

  • Munchausen Syndrome by Proxy (MSBP) involves a parent fabricating or inducing illness in a child to seek attention or sympathy.

Option D - Infantile whiplash syndrome:

  • Infantile whiplash syndrome causes subdural hematoma due to rupture of bridging veins, frequent shaking of the baby, and dot and blot hemorrhages.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of sudden loss of vision in the superior quadrant of the left eye for the past two hours in a 58-year-old man with fundoscopic examination revealing the following finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – CRAO:

  • The given image shows a cherry-red spot. The orange reflex from the intact choroid stands out at the thin foveola, in contrast to the surrounding pale retina, giving rise to a ‘cherry-red spot’ appearance.
  • Sudden sectoral loss of vision and cherry red spots are characteristic of Central Retinal Artery Occlusion.
  • CRAO (Central Retinal Artery Occlusion): CRAO occurs when there is a sudden blockage in the central retinal artery, leading to a severe and immediate loss of vision.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and C are incorrect. The cherry red spot is not a characteristic of these conditions.

questions.text: Which among the following lumbricals communicates with the thenar space?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1st:

  • Lumbrical canal 1 communicates with thenar space while Lumbrical canals 2,3,4 communicate with mid-palmar space.
  • The Lumbricals assist in metacarpophalangeal joint flexion; they contribute to interphalangeal joint extension by acting as deflectors of the proximal interphalangeal Joint.
  • On the other hand, the mid-palmar space is associated with Lumbrical canals 2,3,4, not 1.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C & D are incorrect. Lumbrical canal 1 communicates with thenar space while Lumbrical canals 2,3,4 communicate with mid-palmar space.

questions.text: In a patient with nontoxic multinodular goiter, which of the following increases the risk of a thyroid storm?

choices.text: Administration of saturated solution of potassium iodide for 10 days

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Administration of iodine-containing contrast media:

  • This is a known risk factor for inducing the Jod-Basedow effect in patients with nontoxic multinodular goiter. The iodine load from the contrast media can precipitate hyperthyroidism and potentially a thyroid storm in susceptible individuals.
  • The Jod-Basedow phenomenon (JBP) is a rare condition caused by excessive iodine exposure, also known as iodine-induced hyperthyroidism (IIH). While historically, JBP was seen in iodine-deficient patients when exposed to increased amounts of iodine, today, the most common cause is exposure to iodinated contrast media used in radiological examinations and interventional procedures, leading to significant iodine exposure.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Administration of saturated solution of potassium iodide for 10 days:

  • A saturated solution of potassium iodide (SSKI) is used for 10 days to prevent a thyroid storm by reducing iodide trapping and the production of T4 and T3. This effect is also known as the Wolf-Chaikoff effect.

Option C - Methimazole:

  • Methimazole is an antithyroid medication used to treat hyperthyroidism by inhibiting thyroid hormone synthesis. It helps manage hyperthyroidism and prevent thyroid.

Option D - Cholestyramine:

  • Cholestyramine is a bile acid sequestrant used to lower the levels of thyroid hormones (T4 and T3), hence preventing thyroid storm.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of Brown Sequard syndrome?

choices.text: Proprioception lost on the opposite side
Pain and temperature lost on the opposite side
Pain and temperature lost on the same side
Only pain lost on the same side

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pain and temperature lost on the opposite side:

Brown Sequard syndrome occurs due to the hemisection of the spinal cord affecting ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways.

  • It is characterized by:
    • Damage to ascending sensory pathway:
      • On the side of the lesion: Touch, proprioception, vibration, and tactile discrimination are lost due to damage to the dorsal column pathway.
      • On the opposite side of the lesion: Pain and thermal sensations are lost due to damage to the spinothalamic tract.
    • Damage to the descending motor pathway (corticospinal tract) results in ipsilateral weakness and spasticity.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: Which anticholinergic drug used for the treatment of overactive bladder is preferred for patients with Alzheimer's disease due to its inability to cross the blood-brain barrier?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Trospium:

  • It is preferred for patients with overactive bladder who also have Alzheimer's disease because it does not cross the blood-brain barrier, thus avoiding potential cognitive side effects associated with anticholinergics.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Oxybutynin:

  • Oxybutynin is effective in treating overactive bladder but is the least vesico-selective and can cross the blood-brain barrier, potentially causing cognitive side effects.

Option B – Flavoxate:

  • Flavoxate is used to treat overactive bladder but does not have the specific property of not crossing the blood-brain barrier, making it less ideal for Alzheimer's patients.

Option D – Solifenacin:

  • Solifenacin is the most vesico-selective and least effective, but it can cross the blood-brain barrier and is not specifically preferred for Alzheimer's patients.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the poisoning caused by ingesting seeds of the given flower?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Activation of voltage-gated sodium channels:

  • Aconite poisoning primarily acts by binding to voltage-dependent sodium channels, leading to prolonged action potentials. This results in the excitation of sensory nerves, predominantly affecting sensory nerves over motor nerves. It also causes paralysis of the motor ganglia of the heart and slows the respiratory center. The characteristic cardiac manifestations include tachycardia followed by bradycardia, often leading to cardiac arrhythmias, especially ventricular arrhythmias, which can result in death.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are not the mechanisms of action for aconite poisoning.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an expected complication in a patient with an AFI of 4cm?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cord prolapse:

  • An amniotic fluid index (AFI) <5cm indicates oligohydramnios and cord prolapse is not typically associated with oligohydramnios. It is a complication of polyhydramnios.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D are complications encountered in oligohydramnios.

questions.text: The following instrument in the image is used for?

choices.text: Used to measure the length of the baby till 2 years
Used to measure height after 2 years
Used to measure the weight of a child in the field.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Used to measure the length of the baby till 2 years:

  • The above given image is an infantometer

  • It is a medical device used to measure the length of babies and infants up to 2 years of age.

  • It is specifically designed for this age group, providing accurate measurements of the baby's length while lying down.

  • The infantometer typically consists of a flat, horizontal surface with a movable headpiece or footboard that can be adjusted to align with the baby's head or feet.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B,C, and D are incorrect, as Given above.

questions.text:
Match the given conditions to their recommended treatment:


	
		
			
			1
			
			
			Uterine prolapse
			
			
			a) Posterior colporrhaphy
			
		
		
			
			2
			
			
			Vault prolapse
			
			
			b) Sacrospinous ligament suspension
			
		
		
			
			3
			
			
			Cystocele
			
			
			c) Vaginal hysterectomy
			
		
		
			
			4
			
			
			Rectocele
			
			
			d) Anterior colporrhaphy
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1-c, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a:

1

Uterine prolapse

c) Vaginal hysterectomy

2

Vault prolapse

b) Sacrospinous ligament suspension

3

Cystocele

d) Anterior colporrhaphy

4

Rectocele

a) Posterior colporrhaphy

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D are incorrectly matched.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of abdominal distension. Upon examination, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and orange-colored tonsils are shown in the image. Investigation revealed absent HDL. Mutation in which of the following is responsible for developing this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - ABCA 1:

  • The clinical presentation and image showing orange-colored tonsils are suggestive of tangier disease caused by mutations in the ATP-binding cassette transporter gene.
  • The ABCA1 protein is essential for the regulation of cholesterol efflux from cells to apolipoprotein A-I, which is a key step in the formation of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) particles.
  • Mutations in the ABCA1 gene lead to defective cholesterol transport and result in the characteristic features of Tangier disease, including very low or absent HDL levels in the blood and resulting in hepatosplenomegaly, enlarged lymph nodes, and orange-colored tonsils due to cholesterol deposition.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - NADH Coenzyme Q reductase: Mutation in NADH coenzyme Q reductase results in Leber’s hereditary optic myopathy characterized by blindness in young males.

Option B – CFTR: Mutation in CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator), a chloride conducting channel, results in cystic fibrosis.

Option D – CTNS: Mutations in the CTNS gene cause cystinosis, a lysosomal storage disorder.

Reference: Vasudevan 7th edition. Page no. 342.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with persistent fatigue, shortness of breath, and a dry cough. She also experiences unintentional weight loss and occasional night sweats. Chest X-ray shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and diffuse reticular opacities in the lung fields. Biopsy reveals well-formed, non-caseating granulomas. What anomalies might be expected in further investigations of this patient?

choices.text: Decreased CD4/CD8 ratio in the bronchoalveolar lavage
Elevated serum levels of angiotensin-converting enzyme

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Elevated serum levels of angiotensin-converting enzyme:

  • The given clinical features along with a biopsy showing non-caseating granuloma points towards the diagnosis of sarcoidosis.
  • In cases of sarcoidosis elevated serum levels of angiotensin-converting enzyme is considered a diagnostic feature. In the granulomas of sarcoidosis, angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) is produced by epithelioid cells that are derived from recently activated macrophages.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Decreased CD4/CD8 ratio in the bronchoalveolar lavage: In sarcoidosis, the CD4/CD8 ratio in the bronchoalveolar lavage is typically increased, not decreased.

Option B - Decreased serum levels of calcium: Sarcoidosis is often associated with hypercalcemia due to increased production of active vitamin D by granulomas, leading to increased calcium absorption from the gut.

Option D - Hypocalciuria: Sarcoidosis typically presents with hypercalciuria (increased calcium in the urine), not hypocalciuria, due to the hypercalcemia caused by the disease.

questions.text: What is the limit for blood loss in an LSCS after which intervention is required?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- 1000mL:

  • Blood loss exceeding 1000 mL during or after a cesarean section is considered significant and needs management as per PPH protocols.
  • The average blood loss following vaginal delivery, cesarean delivery, and cesarean hysterectomy is 500 mL, 1000 mL, and 1500 mL, respectively.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male patient was presented with complaints of suprapubic pain, difficulty in passing urine, and blood in urine after a road traffic accident. A retrograde cystogram revealed the following finding. What is the definitive management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Laparotomy:

  • The clinical presentation of suprapubic pain, difficulty passing urine, and hematuria after trauma with retrograde cystogram revealing the outlining of the bowel loops is suggestive of intraperitoneal bladder rupture.
  • The treatment for intraperitoneal bladder rupture involves exploratory laparotomy, peritoneal lavage, repair of the defect, and suprapubic catheter or Foley's  catheterization.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with complaints of fever, cough, and hemoptysis for the past week. He has a history of chronic alcoholism. On further inquiry, he describes his sputum as having a characteristic "red currant jelly" appearance. Which of the following organisms is the likely causative agent of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Klebsiella pneumoniae:

  • Chronic alcoholism significantly increases the risk of developing Klebsiella pneumoniae pneumonia. The thick mucoid capsule of Klebsiella pneumoniae leads to the production of gelatinous sputum, which is often compared to currant jelly. The sputum is typically red colored due to the presence of blood.
  • Klebsiella pneumoniae is part of the normal gut flora. Klebsiella pneumoniae-associated pneumonia is a frequent occurrence among individuals with a predisposition to aspiration (malnutrition, debilitation, chronic alcoholism, and diabetes).

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and D do not commonly cause red currant jelly sputum.

questions.text: What are the constituents of Albert’s stain?

choices.text: Toluidine blue, malachite green and iodine

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Toluidine blue, malachite green, and iodine:

  • The constituents of Albert's stain are as follows:
    • Albert solution 1:
      • Green: Malachite green
      • Purple: Toluidine Blue- shows metachromasia.
    • Albert solution 2: Iodine
    • First, add Toluidine blue, then Iodine, and lastly, Malachite green.
    • On Albert's staining: organism-blue color and volutin granules-purple color.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text:
Match the given conditions to their pattern of inheritance:


	
		
			
			1. Duchenne muscular dystrophy
			
			
			A. Autosomal dominant
			
		
		
			
			2. Leber hereditary optic neuropathy
			
			
			B. X-linked recessive
			
		
		
			
			3. Cystic fibrosis
			
			
			C. Autosomal recessive
			
		
		
			
			4. Myotonic dystrophy
			
			
			D. Mitochondrial
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1-B, 2-D, 3-C, 4-A:

  • Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) - DMD is caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene on the X chromosome.
  • Leber Hereditary Optic Neuropathy (LHON)- Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON) is a rare mitochondrial disorder that typically presents in young males with progressive visual loss due to optic neuropathy. It shows a maternal inheritance pattern, where the condition is passed from mother to offspring but not through the paternal line.
  • Cystic Fibrosis (CF) - CF is caused by mutations in the CFTR gene, which is located on chromosome 7. It follows an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance.
  • Myotonic Dystrophy - Myotonic dystrophy is caused by expansions of a trinucleotide repeat sequence (CTG) in the DMPK gene on chromosome 19. It follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance.

Incorrect Answer:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is an example of the given type of epidemic?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Typhoid:

  • Typhoid is an example of Common Source Epidemics with Continuous or repeated Exposure.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Hepatitis A, polio and vector-borne diseases follow propagated epidemics.

questions.text: A physician decides to use two screening tests in Parallel for breast cancer detection on a patient. Which of the following changes is most likely to occur by using this screening strategy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Sensitivity increases while specificity decreases:

  • For tests in parallel, sensitivity increases and specificity decreases.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect due to the above-given reason.

questions.text:
Match the following parasites with their respective hosts:


	
		
			
			1. Diphyllobothrium

			2. Paragonimus

			3. Brugia

			4. Fasciola
			
			
			a. Sheep

			b. Crab

			c. Cyclops

			d. Mosquitoes
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1-c, 2-b,3-d, 4-a:

Parasites with their respective hosts:

  • Diphyllobothrium spp.
    • Definitive host - Man, 1st Intermediate host - cyclops, 2nd Intermediate host - Fish.
  • Paragonimus spp.
    • Definitive host - Man, 1st Intermediate host - Snail, 2nd Intermediate host - Crab and Fish.
  • Brugia spp.
    • Definitive host - Sheep and Man, Intermediate host - Vector mosquito (Mansonia).
  • Fasciola spp.
    • Definitive host - Man, 1st intermediate host - Snail, 2nd intermediate host - Aquatic plant

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrectly matched.

questions.text: Formication is least likely seen in which of these conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Arachnophobia:

  • Arachnophobia is an extreme fear or aversion to spiders and is not associated with formication, which involves tactile hallucinations unrelated to real insects.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C may be associated with formication:

  • Formication is a tactile hallucination involving the sensation that tiny insects are crawling over the skin. Seen in cocaine addiction, delirium tremens, and psychotic disorders like schizophrenia.

questions.text: A baby assessed at 5 minutes after birth is found to be pink, with blue extremities, a strong cry, and some flexion. The heart rate is 110 beats per minute. There is a grimace reflex upon insertion of the catheter in the nostril. What is the APGAR score for this baby?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – 7:

  • The APGAR score for the newborn is 7.
  • The APGAR score is a quick assessment tool used to evaluate the overall condition and well-being of a newborn immediately after birth.
  • It consists of five components that are:

Parameter

0

1

2

Appearance

Completely blue or pale

The body is pink, and the extremities are blue

Completely pink

Heart rate

Absent

<100/min

>100/min

Reflex irritability

No response

Grimaces only

Coughs/sneezes

Muscle tone

Limp and flaccid

Some flexion is present

Flexed posture and actively moving limbs

Respiration

Absent

Slow and irregular (weak cry)

Normal/strong (strong cry)

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl who has not attained menarche is found to have no uterus on USG and a blind vagina. She is of normal stature and has adequate breast development. A karyotyping showed 46XY. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Androgen insensitivity syndrome:

  • This condition occurs in individuals with a 46XY karyotype. Due to mutations in the androgen receptor, the body cannot respond to male hormones (androgens), leading to the development of female secondary sexual characteristics (such as breast development) and the absence of male internal genitalia. They typically present with a blind-ending vagina and no uterus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - MRKH syndrome:

  • Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome involves Mullerian agenesis leading to the absence of the uterus and upper part of the vagina, but individuals have a 46XX karyotype, not 46XY.

Option B - Mullerian agenesis:

  • Similar to MRKH syndrome, individuals with Mullerian agenesis also have a 46XX karyotype, and it does not fit with the karyotype given (46XY).

Option C - Turner syndrome:

  • Individuals with Turner syndrome typically have a 45X karyotype, not 46XY. They also generally have other physical features and are often of shorter stature.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is brought to the hospital with sudden weakness in her left leg and arm. Despite the severity of her symptoms, she appears remarkably unconcerned. There are no other changes reported in her behavior. She was recently widowed. Upon evaluation, no organic cause for her symptoms was found. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Conversion disorder:

  • Characterized by neurological symptoms (such as paralysis or weakness) that are inconsistent with neurological pathophysiology and cannot be explained by medical evaluation. It often occurs in the context of psychological stress, such as recent bereavement, and is marked by a lack of concern about the symptoms (la belle indifférence).

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Illness Anxiety Disorder: This disorder involves excessive worry about having or acquiring a serious illness, typically without the presence of significant physical symptoms

Option C - Malingering: Involves the intentional production of false or exaggerated symptoms for external incentives, such as financial gain or avoiding responsibilities. Patients usually have a clear motive for their deception.

Option D - Somatic Symptom Disorder: Involves significant distress and preoccupation with physical symptoms, along with excessive thoughts, feelings, or behaviors related to the symptoms.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with a midline neck swelling that moves on deglutition. A USG neck revealed a 3*2 cm nodule on the right lobe of the thyroid extending into the strap muscles. A biopsy was done, and the histological image is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Papillary Carcinoma Thyroid:

  • The histological image showing papillae lined by cells with orphan annie eye nuclei is characteristic of Papillary Carcinoma of the Thyroid (PCT). Orphan Annie Eye nuclei are clear with a ground-glass appearance, which is a hallmark of papillary thyroid carcinoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Follicular Carcinoma Thyroid:

  • Histologically, FCT may show uniform cells forming small follicles containing colloid or sheets of cells containing no colloid.

Option C - Medullary Carcinoma Thyroid:

  • Medullary carcinoma presents with round tumor cells having moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm, round to oval nuclei with granular or "salt and pepper" chromatin and associated amyloid (A).

Option D - Thyroglossal Cyst:

  • A thyroglossal cyst is a congenital cyst that typically presents as a midline neck mass. It represents the persistence of the tract of the thyroid gland.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presenting with lower limb paralysis suggestive of Guillain-Barré syndrome leading to secondary demyelination. Which cells are responsible for myelination of the peripheral nervous system?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Schwann cells:

  • Schwann cells are responsible for the myelination of the peripheral nervous system.
  • When a myelin sheath surrounds a nerve fiber, it is called a myelinated nerve fiber. This sheath is not a part of the neuron but is formed by a supporting cell. This supporting cell in the peripheral nervous system is called the Schwann cell. In the central nervous system, the supporting cell is called an oligodendrocyte. The myelin sheath is a discontinuous, segmented layer interrupted at regular intervals by the nodes of Ranvier.

Incorrect Options:                                                                                                                                                                                                           

Option A - Astrocytes:

  • Astrocytes are a type of microglial cell in the central nervous system. Star-shaped cells maintain the blood-brain barrier and regulate the brain's electrical synapses. They are the most abundant cells. These cells are not responsible for the myelination of the peripheral nervous system.

Option B - Ependymal cells:

  • Ependymal cells form the ventricles' ependymal lining and the spinal cord's central canal and function for CSF production and regulation. These cells are not responsible for the myelination of the peripheral nervous system.

Option D - Microglial cells:

  • Macrophages in the CNS are called microglial cells that remove unwanted neurons and infections and maintain the CNS's overall health. These cells are not responsible for the myelination of the peripheral nervous system.

questions.text: What is the modality of investigation used in the following axial section of the brain?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – T2-weighted MRI:

  • The modality used in the axial section of the brain is T2-weighted MRI.
  • The points of identification are:
    • The bright appearance of CSF (water)
    • Gray matter appears lighter than white matter.

Incorrect Options

Option A – FLAIR: Fluid attenuation inversion recovery is characterized by the dark appearance of CSF (water), and the gray matter appears lighter than the white matter.

Option B - CT scan: In a CT scan, the bone cortex appears white. 

Option C - T1-weighted MRI: It is characterized by dark CSF (water), and the gray matter appears darker than white matter.

questions.text: A woman is scheduled to undergo a laparoscopic hysterectomy. Which of the following is not an advantage of the procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Unapparent extent of thermal burns:

  • A disadvantage of laparoscopic surgery is not knowing the extent of the thermal burns.

Advantages of laparoscopic surgery include:

  • Less blood loss
  • Less postoperative pain
  • Early recovery and shorter post-operative hospitalization
  • Fewer adhesions and more cosmetically advantageous.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are advantages of laparoscopic surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Td vaccine administration in pregnancy is correct for a primigravida in the second trimester?

choices.text: Administering 1 dose in the second trimester
Administering 2 doses, 1 month apart, in the second trimester
Administering 1 dose at any time as soon as possible in pregnancy
Administering 2 doses, 1 month apart, as soon as possible in pregnancy

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Administering 2 doses, 1 month apart, as soon as possible in pregnancy: 

  • For women who are pregnant for the first time or have had their last childbirth more than 3 years ago, the following vaccination schedule is recommended:

    • Two doses of Td vaccine:

      • Vaccine should be administered as soon as possible.

      • Second dose of Td vaccine should be given 4 weeks or 28 days after the first dose.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are incorrect due to the above-given reasons.
